title: labour siding insulate britain instead ordinary working people
story: Conservative MPs and ministers haven’t been slow to condemn the tactics of Insulate Britain, whose campaign to make life as difficult as possible for Britain’s drivers continues apace.But where is Labour in all of this?Were I to compile a list of groups who might naturally and traditionally be considered to be those that Labour is instinctively inclined to defend and stand up for, those seeking to earn a living by driving through a congested city during the day would be near the top. When activists blocked Wandsworth Bridge yesterday morning, angry drivers were filmed doing what the police should have done much earlier: dragging entitled and self-absorbed middle class protesters out of the way. One of the causes of their frustration was that among the hundreds of vehicles forced to grind to a halt was at least one ambulance.NHS workers, delivery vans, school run parents – no one drives through that part of London on a weekday morning for pleasure these were all people with jobs to do and with places they needed to be. And yet Labour MPs said nothing in their defence. If they were angry on behalf of those whose jobs and lives were disrupted, they were keeping quiet about it.Why? The obvious conclusion presents itself: they are frightened (and the word is entirely appropriate) of upsetting the environmental lobby, including many of their own activists.This makes no sense on an electoral level, but on a moral level it is unforgivable.First of all, the electoral. Hardly a day goes by without an analysis being published somewhere of the difficulty Keir Starmer faces in his bid to win the next general election, particularly the task facing him in the so-called Red Wall seats, where traditional working class Labour voters abandoned the party for the Conservatives at the last election.It was an issue that was threatening to rear its head years earlier, when Emily Thornberry posted a tweet mocking St George’s flags and white van owners. And there were no doubt a few white vans held up on Wandsworth Bridge yesterday and perhaps even a few of their drivers helped to clear the road to allow traffic to pass – in itself a community spirited act aimed at helping other road users as much as themselves.Shouldn’t those workers, whether in the north of England or in London, have expected the Labour Party to come to their defence, to decry these protesters for their selfish actions? Does Labour seriously think that holding on to the green vote will help them win back Red Wall seats in Birmingham? Or is it simply that they value, and are more sympathetic to, the kind of voter represented by Insulate Britain activists than to ordinary working class voters who are most impacted by the protests and traffic jams?Unsurprisingly, Insulate Britain’s stoutest defender, George Monbiot, appeared on the radio bulletins yesterday to defend its right to make everyone’s lives a misery on the basis that (in his opinion) their priorities are the correct ones. Setting aside the utter foolishness and historical illiteracy of his comparing these protests with the struggle of the American civil rights movement in the 1950s and ’60s, this is a man who, in 2007, wrote in gleeful anticipation of an economic recession that, while ruining the livelihoods of hundreds of thousands of people, would reduce carbon emissions and was therefore to be welcomed.A more appropriate epitome of metropolitan disdain for the struggle of working class people to earn a living could hardly be imagined. And yet no one in the Labour Party took to the airwaves or social media to call out Monbiot or his tarmac-bothering compatriots. By their inaction they have allowed the Conservative Party to become, by default, the champion of working people. There is no point in referring to the history books and repeating the (now rather pointless) mantra that Labour was created by the trade unions to represent working people: voters will judge today’s politicians by their words and their actions, not by their heritage.Just as there are good electoral reasons for condemning Insulate Britain, the moral reasons for defending them are at best dubious. A decade ago the anti-austerity group UK Uncut decided that the best way to force retail boss Philip Green to pay more tax was to make life difficult for shoppers in the run-up to Christmas. As in 2021, those who relished the misery they caused to people desperately trying to buy gifts for their families believed their own cause was so pure that they had the moral authority to do what they liked. I was one of the few Labour MPs at the time to condemn their spoiled brat behaviour and received a fair amount of abuse in return. Is that what today’s horny-handed sons (and daughters) of toil in the Parliamentary Labour Party are afraid of? A few ill-tempered tweets? If losing a few Twitter followers is a price too high for Labour MPs to pay for standing up for the rights of working people to go about their business unencumbered by virtue-signalling eco-warriors, I really doubt if they would ever be willing to make the changes that are necessary to see their party become the natural choice once more of Britain’s working class voters.More from NewsBoris can’t defy the laws of political gravity foreverTurn to family first – not the state – for social care support, says Sajid JavidMinister promises annual mental health ‘MOT’ for all Armed ForcesEthnic minority charity welcomes return of blackface Morris dancersNew league tables will expose police forces that fail rape victimsPriti Patel launches inquiry into how ‘monster’ Wayne Couzens was able to work as police officerMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: royal navy submarine jousts japanese show strength aimed china
story: A Royal Navy submarine has taken on the Japanese navy in the first training exercise of its kind in a show of strength to China.The exercise last month involved “thousands of tons of steel in a game of cat and mouse” a former Royal Navy anti-submarine frigate captain told the .The Japanese navy said it had conducted “a bilateral exercise with the Royal Navy in order to strengthen cooperation and realise a free and open Indo-Pacific”.The exercise took place on Sept 14 and 15, the Japanese navy said.The deepening defence relationship between Britain and Japan and the forging of new friendships in the region is likely to anger China.Taking place in waters off Japan, the drills were part of the ongoing deployment of the UK Carrier Strike Group, based around HMS Queen Elizabeth, Britain’s newest operational aircraft carrier.The Royal Navy’s nuclear-powered Astute-class submarine would likely have gone up against a Soryu-class diesel-electric boat from the Japanese navy.Tom Sharpe, a former commander in the Royal Navy and an anti-submarine warfare specialist, said the interaction demonstrated the “width of soft and hard power options a carrier strike group brings to the table”.“This is a strategically vital part of the world, with the Chinese army and Air Force currently and repeatedly encroaching Taiwanese airspace.“This is the sort of exercise that strengthens everything from strategic alliances to tactical operating procedures.“VIP visits, group formations and freedom of navigation operations photograph well and tend to capture the headlines.“Meanwhile, underwater, far from any cameras, thousands of tons of steel are engaged in a game of cat and mouse, the implications of which will resonate from the very highest levels of political alliance-forming to the operators in the respective submarine control rooms.”Diesel-electric submarines are often quieter than nuclear powered boats when submerged, due to the noise generated by the primary coolant pumps around the reactor.Even so, nuclear submarines are more highly prized as they can operate for longer, deeper and at greater ranges than diesel-electric boats.Taro Kono, the leading candidate to succeed Yoshihide Suga, Japan’s outgoing prime minister, has expressed support for transitioning Japan’s 20-strong submarine force to nuclear powered vessels, given the increasing threat from China.These drills are likely to have emboldened calls for Japan’s submarines to adopt nuclear power and come just weeks after Australia agreed to develop such a fleet with Britain and the US.The exercise would have been tightly controlled to prevent an inadvertent collision underwater.The British and Japanese boats would likely have taken it in turns to be the hunter force. Each would have operated in an area of roughly 20 square miles, with the boxes separated laterally by at least a mile.Without surface ships present, the submarines will have practised search and attack phases. If warships were involved, it is likely one submarine would have been assigned to the surface group and the other would act as the aggressor, trying to get a clean shot on the group’s mission critical ship.Mr Sharpe said the ultra quiet submarines would have been “holes in the ocean” throughout the exercise, as each tried to get a firing solution on the other.The key vulnerability of diesel-electric submarines is the necessity to come to periscope depth periodically, to “snort” fresh air whilst running the diesel engines to recharge the batteries. It is not known if the Japanese boat had to conduct this procedure.The British hunter-killer submarine would have been able to remain submerged throughout the exercise.A Ministry of Defence spokesperson said: “Japan is one of our closest strategic partners. The ability to integrate militarily with allies and partners has been the hallmark of this global deployment”.More from NewsBoris can’t defy the laws of political gravity foreverTurn to family first – not the state – for social care support, says Sajid JavidMinister promises annual mental health ‘MOT’ for all Armed ForcesEthnic minority charity welcomes return of blackface Morris dancersNew league tables will expose police forces that fail rape victimsPriti Patel launches inquiry into how ‘monster’ Wayne Couzens was able to work as police officerMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: seven sides sunak meet sporty silicon sidekick rest
story: With the majority of Cabinet ministers, it’s easy to imagine what their action figure would look like. Boris Johnson? An unironed navy sock filled with sausage meat, nipped and loosely tucked to create limbs, with some Chipsticks glued to the top as a hairstyle. Pull the string on his back and he could conjure nine different authentic blathering sounds. Michael Gove? Just take the original Parker puppet from Thunderbirds, treble the size of the lips, pop some little spectacles on, and hope it doesn’t scare children when it dances. Priti Patel? Smiling-scowling, and wearing a tiny version of that personalised National Crime Agency jacket she wore while rubbernecking on some immigration raids in May. But when it comes to Rishi Sunak, what does that doll look like? When you think of our diminutive Chancellor, more than half a dozen different characters could spring to mind. Yesterday, we saw him suited and booted and energetic and telling us the future is HERE and it’s TIME to seize it at the Conservative Party conference in Manchester. Before that he was clad in traffic cone orange, helping Boris Johnson to point at things on a Manchester construction site. The day before that he was in his hoodie, being the chilled out wealthy tech bro he frequently projects. There are, at a conservative estimate, at least seven sides to Sunak. He is the heptahedron of British politics. The chameleon of the Cabinet. The real Rishi may never stand up, but let us count his ways, in order of how frequently we see them. Like swallowing spiders in our sleep, we probably don’t even realise how often we see Rishi Sunak’s signature every week. Hundreds, possibly. It’s there on almost every social media post from either his personal account or that of the Treasury, on official literature, on slides, in adverts and at media briefings. And that’s notwithstanding how often it haunts our dreams. Brand Sunak – which kick-started during the pandemic, when the Chancellor’s autograph started appearing on fiscal pledges like he’s Eric Bristow personally endorsing a dartboard – is the most relentless online campaign since Cadbury released the Orange Twirl. And just like that piece of confectionary, Sunak in theory is far more appetising than Sunak in practice. It’s easy to forget, when you read the column inches (sorry) he commands, see the way he presents himself, hear him speak, or regard the way Boris Johnson looks in comparison – but Rishi Sunak is not in fact the Prime Minister. He’s not even the Deputy Prime Minister – that title was used recently as a dummy to soothe an incessantly wailing Dominic Raab. No, Sunak’s at best third in command, a role he occasionally has to fill by standing next to Boris Johnson in Parliament, on walkabouts and at lecterns.Many people of the Chancellor’s ambition would find it galling to have to meekly nod while their boss takes the limelight, but remember that this man’s boss is somebody who only has to be near a room to make everybody else in it seem shevelled and tactful. So Sunak is unlikely to mind.“Whaddup guys! Gah, feels so good to be out of that suit jacket and tie – so stiff, so formal, so not my vibe, but The Man makes me wear a suit so I’ve gotta play the game in order to change the score, amiright? No, I’m much more comfortable in this, a very thin £46 grey hoodie from Everlane, which I wear whenever I am eager to transmit what my advisors dub Silicon Valleycat Energy. “I wear my thin grey hoodie about as much as Rocky Balboa wears his. It’s the sartorial equivalent of spinning a chair around and straddling it backwards, they say. It’s the perfect contrast to Boris, who literally goes running in a collared dress shirt, they say. It’s me.”“How does he look so trim and fresh?” people asked of Sunak last year, when he appeared looking lithe and pristine at every Covid press conference, while Chris Whitty wore the signs of running on 30 minutes’ sleep, and Boris Johnson looked like Boris Johnson. The answer came when Sunak admitted that he owns a Peloton, a type of very expensive exercise bike which seems to come with a stipulation that all users must tell everyone they know that they are converts, like Mormonism or polyamory. Sunak is up at 6am to cycle, he has told us, and his favourite Peloton instructor is a 33-year-old New Yorker called Cody Rigsby. “You do have to listen to a lot of Britney,” Sunak said. “But you know, no bad thing in trying to get you motivated, I guess.” He then has a Greek yoghurt, or a Mexican Coke, or just a bit of chicken broth, if he’s intermittently fasting. The actual day job. The navy suit might be designer and tailored to his body, but it’s still the uniform of a working politician, and that’s certainly one of Sunak’s many personas. Sometimes – not as often as we’d like, but sometimes – he just gets on with the job of government, and presents that way to the public: as a person with a responsible job who is doing it diligently and well. Occasionally, Sunak reminds us that he is a former banker and hedge fund manager whose wife, Akshata, is said to be wealthier than the Queen, and herself the daughter of N.R. Narayana Murthy, one of the wealthiest men in India. Designer suits, fur-lined jackets that somehow emanate wealth, a general air of money… In some ways it makes sense to put in charge of the country’s GDP one of the few people to be used to dealing with that amount of zeros just when they open their joint account, but Sunak, a fairly private man when it comes to his family, tries to play that down. He can’t hide it, though.The side we’ll see more and more. title: survey reveals poem uk voters believe greatest ever written
story: Rough winds may shake the darling buds of May, but not the enduring popularity of Shakespeare’s verse, as the Bard’s Sonnet 18 has been voted the greatest poem of all time.The work, which begins “Shall I compare thee to a summer’s day?”, has polled first in a UK-wide survey on the nation’s favourite poetry.Despite being written 400 years ago, the 14-line rumination on beauty, time, and the immortality of art has lived on in the public imagination and was chosen ahead of more modern verse.The 18th poem in William Shakespeare’s cycle of 154 sonnets was voted for by 18 per cent of those surveyed for their literary favourites, ahead of works by other evergreen poets including William Wordsworth and John Keats.The poem is part of the “Fair Youth” sequence of sonnets, which are believed to be addressed to a beautiful young man and romantic interest.While the work seems a straightforward poem extolling beauty, like the others which precede it in the collection of sonnets first published in 1609, it signs off with a couplet declaring that only his verse will make the youth immortal: “So long as men can breathe or eyes can see”.The sonnet was chosen ahead of Wordsworth’s rhapsodising nature poem I Wandered Lonely as a Cloud (also commonly known as “Daffodils”), conjuring the beauty of the Lake District, which was picked by 10 per cent of those surveyed.American writer Edgar Allen Poe’s gothic work The Raven was chosen by 9 per cent of respondents in a survey by research group Perspectus Global, as was Rudyard Kipling’s stoic poem If.Traditional poets of the English canon appear in the top 20 list, which includes William Blake’s The Tyger, Lord Byron’s She Walks in Beauty, and Wilfred Owen’s First World War work Dulce et Decorum est.But more modern verse also appears on the list, with Benjamin Zephaniah’s Dis Poetry and Maya Angelou’s poem Still I Rise also being cited in the survey, along with Carol Ann Duffy’s The Way My Mother Speaks.While modern works such as the song Cat D, by spoken word artist George the Poet, appears on the list, Shakespeare’s 17th-century sonnet remained the most cited poem in the survey.Although a love poem polled first, and several amorous works are included in the top 20, the survey found that, online, only one in 10 people in the UK could contemplate reciting romantic verse.More from NewsTurn to family first – not the state – for social care support, says Sajid JavidMinister promises annual mental health ‘MOT’ for all Armed ForcesEthnic minority charity welcomes title: british officials sit down talks
story: :root British officials sit down for talks with Taliban leaders in Afghanistan for first timeBoris Johnsons special envoy to the war-torn country pressed Taliban chiefs on humanitarian crisis and urged them not to let Afghanistan become a haven for terrorismTaliban fighters on the streets of Kabul as Afghanistan fell Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  Oct | commentsBritish officials have travelled to war-torn Afghanistan to meet Taliban leaders for the first time since the chaotic fall of Kabul. Boris Johnsonaposs special envoy to Afghanistan, Sir Simon Gass, sat down with the group to discuss the humanitarian crisis facing the country. The top diplomat also told them they had a duty to make sure the nation did not once again descend into a haven for terrorists. Foreign Office officials said Sir Simon stressed the need for continued safe passage for Afghans who had helped the British mission who wanted to leave. And he raised the treatment of women and girls after the Taliban effectively banned girls from secondary education by ordering high schools to re-open only for boys.  The talks are a signicant development as they suggest that UK efforts to help thousands more people leave the country remain a priority. The Taliban has been in control since the fall of the western-backed government in August, which followed the chaotic withdrawal of US and UK troops. Britain does not intend to recognise the Taliban as the government of Afghanistan any time in the near future. But ex-foreign secretary Dominic Raab announced earlier this month that the UK would start engaging directly with the Islamist group.  Defence Secretary Ben Wallace warned that the military withdrawal from Afghanistan had created opportunities for both China and Islamist terrorists. He told a fringe event at the Conservative Party conference in Manchester: Who popped up immediately as the US and Nato were leaving, but China, offering to invest in Afghanistan  That was about securing land routes to ports such as Karachi and also into Pakistan. He added: It is all connected. The ripples from Afghanistan will be felt by al-Shabaab in Somalia, and of course al-Shabaab pose a threat to British interests and to our friends in Kenya. The ripples of another superpower being portrayed as defeated by Islamic terrorism will be felt across the world.   The PMaposs envoy Sir Simon met Taliban leaders including Amir Khan Muttaqi, Mullah Abdul Ghani Baradar and Abdul Salam Hanafi. A foreign office spokesman said: They discussed how the UK could help Afghanistan to address the humanitarian crisis, the importance of preventing the country from becoming an incubator for terrorism, and theneed for continued safe passage for those who want to leave the country. They also raised the treatment of minorities and the rights of women and girls. “The Government continues to do all it can to ensure safe passage for those who wish to leave, and is committed to supporting the people of Afghanistan.”Comment MORE ON Taliban AfghanistanAfghanistanForeign OfficePolitics" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. out plans to water down Human Rights protections for Brits today - citing a misleading, decade old case as evidence for the need to aposoverhaulapos the law. The facts of the case were not exactly as Mr Raab suggested in his speech.And it came almost ten years to the day after Theresa May sparked fury by ly claiming a man had been protected from deportation because he had a cat.In fact, Mrs May even mentioned the man seized upon by Mr Raab today in her speech in . The newly minted Justice Secretary used his speech to Conservative Party Conference to complain that laws were being abused by dangerous criminals. And he claimed a drug dealer convicted of beating his ex-partner, a man who hadnapost paid maintenance for his daughter, then successfully claimed the right to family le to avoid deportation.  The criminal in question was Trinidadian-born Asim Parris. Then-Home Secretary Jacqui Smith had originally ordered Parrisapos deportation in  after he had been jailed for  months for possession of cocaine with intent to supply. A year earlier, he had been convicted of battery against his partner and given a suspended sentence. But his argument to be prevented from deportation was not based on his former partner or daughter, but on his being  years old and having lived in the UK since he was four. He appealed and in  the Immigration Tribunal allowed him to stay, noting he had close family in this country including his mother, sisters, brother, cousin, nieces and nephews, uncle and aunt.  And at the original appeal, his former partner told the tribunal that while they were no longer in a relationship he was a good and caring father and the judges said she and Parris appear[ed] to be on good terms. Within minutes of the speech, the Judicial Office at the Royal Courts of Justice had pointed out that it was untrue, and that the cat had nothing to do with the decision. title: i cant words sarah everards
story: :root I cant get words of Sarah Everard’s mum out my head, but Boris Johnson isnt listeningIn the aftermath of Sarah Everards death and her mums heartbreaking words, Boris Johnsons verdict on misogyny is unforgivable and makes Polly Hudson glad she doesnt have a daughterBoris Johnson refuses to categorise misogyny as a hate crime Image: PAopinionByPolly Hudson:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct It sounds like the punchline to the least funny joke ever told, but Boris Johnson doesn’t think misogyny is a hate crime. He’s refused to categorise it as such, to give a clear sign to women that, despite what we think, feel, and experience, we DO matter. He believes that, “ you simply widen the scope of what you ask the police to do, you’ll just increase the problem”.Not taking violence against women seriously enough would be a horrendous move at any time, but in the aftermath of Sarah Everard ’s death, it’s unforgivable.I can’t get her mum’s victim impact statement out of my head. Pulsating with palpable agony, it painted a vivid picture of losing a child in the worst way imaginable. I doubt anyone who read it will ever forget it, or – eventhe memory of the exact words eventually fade – how it made them feel. Get all the latest news straight to your inbox.to one of the Mirroraposs newsletters “He treated my daughter asshe was nothing and disposed of her asshe was rubbish,” Susan Everard wrote about her precious little girl. Despite Sarah’s death, and Sabina Nessa ’s, and the  women who were killed by men in between, and all the women before them, nothing is being done. Those in power are spouting platitudes, but no real action is being taken. In  two people died as a result of terrorism, while  women were murdered by men, but there is no Counter Femicide Unit.As much as I hate to admit it, I’m currently feeling very glad that I don’t have a daughter. Because what are you meant to tell your her  How do you play it  Do you dismay her, destroy her, with the awful truth from the off, so she has realistic expectations   Or do you pretend she’ll be treated the same way as the boys she grows up alongside  Act like she won’t be belittled, objectied, chased, discounted, talked over, disrespected, laughed at, attacked – raped, killed even  My neighbour’s daughter started walking home from our local primary on her own last spring, in preparation for the big move to secondary school. I happened to see her trotting past proudly one day, clearly revelling in being so grown up. Before the week was out, some bloke had shouted at her from a car, leered at her, beeped his horn aggressively. Now she’s scared to walk anywhere alone. She was allowed three whole days of feeling empowered, independent, in control, before a man robbed her of it with a few careless words. Innocence shattered by age . Worst of all  Maybe it’s a good thing. Now she’s in no doubt what she’s up against. Perhaps it’s our duty to arm every young girl with the cold, hard reality of the situation, so their spirits aren’t entirely broken by learning it the hard way, ad nauseam. The truth is women can play men at their own games, beat them at their own jobs, know more than them, earn more than them, outsmart them, be every bit as capable, intelligent, resilient, funny, qualied… None of that matters. They are physically stronger. They can kill usthey want to. Simple as that. Women are screaming for help at the moment. We have been for a long time. title: tory chief orders civil servants
story: :root Tory chief orders civil servants to get off their Pelotons and back to their desksOliver Dowden appeared to be having a jibe at the former top civil servant in his own department - and was accused of being out of touchOliver Dowden wearing a Tory scum badge that was handed to him at the event today Image: REUTERSByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Oct | commentsThe chairman of the Conservative Party has sparked a backlash after telling civil servants to “get off their Pelotons and back to their desks”. Oliver Dowden bizarrely suggested civil servants were widespread owners of the high-end exercise bike, which costs £, plus a £-a-month subscription. He also made the claim just weeks after his own government unveiled plans to let workers request flexible working - including home working - from Day One in a job. Mr Dowden told aconference fringe event: People really want the Government to lead by example, they want civil servants to get back to work. We have got to start leading by example on that. He added: People need to get off their Pelotons and get back to their desks. Chancellor Rishi Sunak is among the lucky Brits rich enough to own a Peloton.  But the comment appears to be a jibe at the most senior civil servant in the Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport, where Mr Dowden was until recently the top minister. Permanent Secretary Sarah Healey reportedly told a tech conference she liked working from home, because “I have a Peloton and I can just get on my bike whenever I have a teeny bit of time. “That has been a huge benefit to my well-being, the lack of travelling time eating into my day.” Mr Dowden also claimed billionaires who donate £, and get dinners with the Prime Minister do so out of “civic duty”. Labour chair Anneliese Dodds said: Oliver Dowden thinks people are sitting at home on Pelotonsinstead of working.And that billionaires are donating hundreds of thousands of pounds to the Conservative Party out of a sense of civic duty. How out of touch can you get  Twitter user ‘Ferret’ said: “Basic Peloton costs £ upwards, much more at the height of the pandemic. Many working class people worked all the way through. Not sure who he’s dissing here and who he’s trying to appeal to.”Consultant Sharon O’Dea tweeted: With the median UK Civil Service salary £, and a Peloton bike +  year subscription coming in at £,, Iaposm going to go out on a limb and say the number of civil servants too busy working out on posh exercise bikes to go to the office is in the single figures at most.” Read more It is part of an attack on home-working by Tory ministers, despite the government’s own plans to make it easier to request flexible work. Another Tory MP, Jake Berry, this week accused civil servants of ‘woke-ing’ from home.And Boris Johnson is set to launch a push towards home working in his keynote speech in Manchester tomorrow.The PM said: I think that for young people in particular, it is really essential to be in a...youaposre going to learn on the job, you canapost just do it on Zoom. Youaposve got to be able to come in and sit at the... youaposve got to know what everyone  is talking about. Otherwise, youaposre going to be gossiped about and youaposre going to lose out. You need to be there, and you have the stimulus of exchange and competition. title: tory co chair confronted party
story: :root Tory co-chair confronted at party conference over cash-for-access rowBen Elliot refused to answer questions over allegations he organised meetings between businessmen and his uncle Prince CharlesTory co-chairman Ben Elliot was challenged Sky News at Conservative conference Image: Sky NewsByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political EditorDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Oct | commentsTory co-chairman Ben Elliot has been confronted on camera at Conservative conference over allegations of cash for access to Prince Charles. Mr Elliot was doorstepped by Sky News at the event in Manchester, where he was repeatedly grilled over allegations he had organised meetings between businessmen and the future king. The -year-old is the Duchess of Cornwall’s nephew and a director of Quintessentially - a “luxury lestyle management service” for the super-rich. He was dragged into a row when Quintessentially subscriber and Tory donor Mohamed Amersi claimed in July that Mr Elliot arranged for him to meet Prince Charles - after years of subscription payments. The Registrar of Consultant Lobbyists found Mr Elliot did not need to register as a lobbyist but had advised him to be cautious about making a distinction between his Quintessentially role and his activities linked to the Government.  Asked repeatedlyhe was offering access to his uncle Prince Charles for money, Mr Elliot remained tight-lipped. He also didnapost answer questions about whether there was a conflict of interest between his work and his role at the Tory party. He told Sky News reporter Joe Pike: Iaposm going to have a curry nowthataposs ok, before adding: I wish youaposd stop following me. Mr Amersi claimed at the time: “I call it access capitalism… You get access, you get invitations, you get privileged relationshipsyou are part of the set-up, and where you are financially making a contribution to be a part of that set up. The Registrar of Consultant Lobbyists found Mr Elliot did not need to register as a lobbyist, but it advised him “to be cautious about the possibility of engaging in consultant lobbying activityby not making a clear enough distinction between his role as a director of Quintessentially and his other activities connected to government.” A spokesperson on behalf of Mr Elliot said at the time: “The registrar has made clear that Quintessentially does not lobby Government and therefore does not need to register as a lobbyist.” Tory chairman Oliver Dowden launched a furious defence of Mr Elliot, branding him “fantastic”. He told a fringe event hosted by The : “Ben is a fantastic man and one of the great fundraisers of the Conservative Party. “He was the person who powered the election victory in  - he’s broadened our base of supporters and brings a great deal of expertise. “We’re getting along great”. Mr Dowden dismissed press questions about Mr Elliot’s financial arrangements, claiming “I have seen this every single time” with other fundraisers. He added: “I don’t believe Ben Elliot has done anything wrong, he’s properly separated his interests and so on.” It comes as Mr Amersi, who has given more than £, to the Conservatives since , was linked to a major corruption scandal. The so-called Pandora Papers documents reveal the -year-old corporate lawyer advised on a series of deals for a Swedish telecoms company, according to the BBC. The firm, Telia, later accepted the mdeal was a corrupt payment - a bribe for the daughter of the then-president of Uzbekistan. Mr Amersi denies any wrongdoing.Asked about the revelations, Boris Johnson insisted the Tory party vets donors all the time.Comment MORE ON Royal FamilyConservative Party" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: :root Tory MP blasts own governments foolish and unfair Universal Credit cut to millionsTory MP Nigel Mills said the Tories risk looking cruel and harsh as Boris Johnson steams ahead with a cut that formally takes effect tomorrowBoris Johnson is about to steer hundreds of thousands of families into poverty Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | comments A Tory MP today blasted his own party’s “foolish and unfair” £-a-week cut to Universal Credit for millions of Brits.Nigel Mills warned the Conservatives risk looking “cruel and harsh” and “leaving people in an impossible situation” as the brutal cut kicks in from next week.The cut will formally begin tomorrow - just as Boris Johnson addresses the Tory conference - and hit payments arriving between October  and November .Some .million people plus more than million children will be affected. Yet the cruel Prime Minister defended the cut today by claiming it was wrong for taxpayers to “subsidise” low wages. The benefit system has done this for decades and % of claimants are in work. Tory MP Nigel Mills, who sits on the Commons Work and Pensions Committee, told a conference fringe event in Manchester: “I think the government are being a little bit foolish I think politically and they’re being unfair on people by taking that away.  “I sense by the end of October the government may have realised that probably wasn’t the…having spent months wanting the government to stand up and not back down every time something got dficult, I think they’ve picked the wrong issue to start with. “No doubt we will see in a few weeks with the rising cost of living how bad a decision that is.” Mr Mills slammed the new Household Support Fund, sayingministers had £m to spend on “creating very complicated funds” people have to apply for, spending money on the benefit itself would be a better use of money. Speaking to the Bright Blue fringe, Mr Mills said unlike a decade ago, “I don’t think there’s the same political concern that welfare’s too high and it’s too easy. I think we should be very careful we’re not playing the politics of a decade ago when there was a problem to fix. Now there actually isn’t one. Read more “And we actually may end up going so far that we look cruel and harsh and leaving people in an impossible situation that no one wants to see - everybody has grandchildren or friends who will end up in this situation.” Tory MP Peter Aldous said it was “wrong” to be taking away the £-a-week now when Britain had just seen its worst economic shock in a century. He warned costs are “cascading in” on families, telling the fringe event: “The idea we just switch on the light and go back to normal is not going to happen. “Covid is going to have a very long tail and we’ve seen that in the last  days with the crisis in the energy sector, there are challenges with regard to food, housing costs and rents.” Mr Aldous said many claimants are “not in a position now” to take up vacancies. He added: “It’s probably not consistent with the levelling up agenda. The levelling up agenda has a lot of focus quite rightly on infrastructure.  “But actually equipping and providing people with the skills to take up those jobs, and as Conservatives provide a fair benefits system, a safety net that provides you with some degree of security…. I think we have made a mistake.” Boris Johnson earlier defended the £-a-week cut to Universal Credit that will plunge hundreds of thousands of families into poverty. The Prime Minister argued that businesses should put up wages rather than taxpayers subsidising them through the welfare system. But low-income families face the triple whammy of rising prices and energy bills along with falling income support this winter. In a round of broadcast interviews, Mr Johnson said: I understand that people feel times are dficult at the moment because we have got an economy thataposs coming out of a very tough period with the Covid pandemic. He added: What we wonapost do is take more money in tax to subsidise low pay through the welfare system.The Government has been in an escalating row with Labour, unions, landlords, debt charities and Tory MPs, including former welfare secretaries, who want it to cancel the cut.But ministers claim the plan is the “right way to help people” by focusing on those in work, even though % of claimants already have a job. title: bargain hunting couple turn plain
story: :root Bargain hunting couple turn plain rented terraced house into stunning home for £Flo Sandler and her photographer husband, Oli Sandler, from Medway, Kent, have filled their two bedroom property with colourful wall art, canvases and furnitureFlo Sandler, , has put her bargain hunting skills to good use by helping to decorate the rental house Image: @florisinaforest   CATERS NEWSByTim Hanlon:,  Oct | commentsA couple of bargain hunters with an eye for colourful design have turned an average rented terrace house into a stunning home for just £. Flo Sandler, , and her photographer husband, Oli Sandler, , from Medway, Kent, moved into their rented, terraced  bed property in . Now the plain home has now been redesigned with amazing wall art, canvases and furniture, all with a bold and colourful feel. Yet despite the incredible look of the house, Flo has only spent an astounding £ on the project. The jewellery production manager, said: The vinyl printed wall art came to a total of £, with the wall tape and paint amounting to an additional £ and the remaining furniture and d cor costing £. Flo has a knack for bargain hunting, although interior design on a budget was never her first intention. She said: Money was never really an object for me, but Iaposve always been good at finding uses for cheaper things and reusing items. Itaposs been a big factor to my creative process, I would always rather collect the materials first and then see where I am instead of spending loads of money on the finished product. As it is a rented home, I never wanted to spend loads on something I wasnapost always going to be in, however it was also important for me to be comfortable and to enjoy my home. Flo started the project at the beginning of lockdown last year, after previously struggling with her mental health.  When the lockdown was first started, it gave me a chance to get back in touch with my creativity, she said. It was incredibly therapeutic and great for my healing process after a dficult period of time. I have always been a creative person, regularly designing clothing and jewellery when I was younger, but I always wanted to get into interior design.Flo credits online s like Instagram and Pinterest for giving her confidence and inspiration.She said:I never had the confidence to go for it until I started interacting more with the online communities. They are so informative and helped give me inspiration for my own ideas of removable decor for rented homes, and to take existing things and put my own spin on them. I have used my Instagram page as a creative log where Iaposve regularly updated our homeaposs journey. Floaposs favourite rooms in the home are her two bedrooms located upstairs in her home.  She added: We have two bedrooms upstairs and the main bedroom is more laid back and relaxed which I love. My usual style is sort of everything, everywhere but this room was a little more considered more mature than the rest of my style. The spare room has been unoccupied for the whole of lockdown and beyond really, so I just went full out and had loads of stuff in there. Her favourite pieces of furniture in the house were very dficult for her to decide on. She said: I noticed a trend in the online community with colourful, upcycled drinks trolleys which I thought was really cool. I bought myself one and the gold colour was really faded so I spray painted it bright pink, which I am really proud of it, it was simple but effective. I also recently tried leather painting a smaller green, modular sofa bench we have which I was also really happy with. Floaposs husband, Oli, has always been supportive of her creativity at home. Flo said: He isnapost really involved in the styling, but he loves taking pictures of the home for the Instagram page, so I think we make a good team.  He enjoys being surrounded by something thataposs a bit dferent, and it is always fun to have people over and see their reactions. Itaposs been a journey, and there has definitely been times where we havenapost been on the same page with ideas, but we always share our opinions and its very democratic. Floaposs friends and family have always also been really positive when it comes to her home design. She added: I cannot ever recall any negative comments we have had from loved ones, but we have definitely had some negative comments online which people see to have more confidence in sharing when they do not know you. Funnily enough, our landlord has never been the biggest fan of the project, but he is aware that everything is removable and not permanent, so he is understanding.  He is a carpenter and when we moved in the house was full of quirky wooden features which we both loved, but it was just too bland, and I always knew I wanted to add my own touch to it. The couple are expecting a baby in February next year, and are planning to leave their property soon, as they have recently bought their first home together. Flo said: Itaposs a really exciting time for us right now and I am sure when we are moved in at some point, I will start designing again. As we are excepting though it is definitely getting put on the back-burner for some much-needed rest and relaxation! news uk-news boy--who-struggled-anxiety-"Mirror Head Strong campaign: Jo McMeechan reveals how lockdown has affected her childrens mental healthByNatasha Wynarczyk:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA mum has told how her son became so anxious during the lockdown that he ran into traffic to avoid crowds. Jo McMeechan, , lives in Bristol with her husband Alex, , and their two sons Rory, , and Arthur, . During the pandemic Jo, who is a paediatric physiotherapist, has seen both her children have mental health problems.A week before lockdown was announced, Jo and Alex decided to shield their household, as Rory had just recovered from sepsis and had severe asthma, making him extremely vulnerable to coronavirus.However, this “signicantly impacted” Rory’s mental health. “He really struggled, especially with the social isolation,” said Jo.   “He missed his friends and had limited opportunities to safely get outdoors as the advice for him was to shield for  weeks. Rory struggled to sleep and had no motivation for anything, and he also became very tearful and distressed most days. He couldn’t understand why he wasn’t allowed to socialise with his friends.” Jo said that when schools reopened for the children of key workers, she made the decision to send Rory back, as he just wasn’t coping with the social isolation. “My husband and I were seriously concerned about the effect this would have on him in the long-term,” she said. “We thought the risk of Covid was less than the damage to his mental health, so we took a key worker place at his school for him and the dference that we saw in him as the social isolation lted and his education became more stable was incredible. However, I still don’t feel he is fully back to how he was before the pandemic.”  Jo and Alex’s younger son Arthur however struggled with coming out of lockdown. Arthur is Autistic and has ADHD, as well as Sensory Processing Disorder which means he has problems with sitting still, focusing, and regulating his emotions. “On the flipside, Arthur really well during the pandemic, but going back to socialising has been a real challenge as his anxiety is through the roof,” said Jo. “He’s had to go back to school on a reduced timetable of  minutes a day at most. We have a lot of dficulties taking Arthur out without it causing him distress. He’s run out of school gates towards traffic to avoid crowds or hidden in bushes to avoid people. “It’s been very challenging, especially now things have fully opened up.  He wants to do things but gets too overwhelmed. Recently we went to our local harvest fair and he got out on the green and saw the crowds of people and sat down hugging his knees and refused to move. “Before the pandemic, this was never a signicant issue for Arthur. He would have thrived in those situations before.” Jo said her and Alex were left managing their children’s mental health by themselves. “We talked to their school about getting help from the nursing team there, but we were told access to resources was zilch and there was pretty much nothing available for us,” said Jo. “From my experience as a health professional, a lot of our community teams were redistributed to Covid or were having to isolate meaning there were not enough people working in a system that was already overstretched, so although we discussed access to help for the boys it seemed asit was going to be a futile quest for a referral. It has been so hard for my family.” Rory and Arthur are two of several children the Mirror has reported on to expose the impact of the pandemic on their mental health.The Daily Mirror is launching our new campaign HeadStrong: Better Mental Health For All. We’re calling for:Early Access Mental Health Hubs for under s to be rolled out across the country, with at least one for each trust. Waiting times to be cut so people actually start treatment with a professional within four weeks The Govt to fill in the gaps in care - an end of red tape which means many don’t fit the set criteria to get help plus , more mental health staffCompulsory Mental Health education lessons in schools, plus paid counsellors in schools and care homesWant to help  Write to your MP and ask them to support the current Early Day Motion  to debate mental health and the pandemic in parliament. Itaposs thought some .m more children will need help in the next three to five years because of the past  months - whether it be because the pandemic has triggered or exacerbated a mental health health issue. The numbers of under s suffering from anxiety, low mood, depression, eating disorders and OCD have all rocketed since the first lockdown. But unfortunately the childrenaposs mental health services were already at breaking point before Covid. How to get help: If you are struggling or you are worried about a loved one, contact Samaritans on . She added: He knew that I was orced, he knew that I was vulnerable and he knew that I was probably low. There is a very high emotional cost with it all, but my story has to be told.Peter McMahonaposs whereabouts remains unknown but according to American news site SiLive, he was arrested for allegedly creating a fake festival to benefit autistic children in Staten Island in .Ruth is now happily married in Leeds and is getting ready to publish a book about her horror ordeal.To keep up to date with her work visit her website here. story: :root Drivers at one of UKs biggest shopping centres hit with fines in free car parkThe fight for a parking spot has led many shoppers to park on pavements, double lines, and inside disabled bays without permits. After three car parks at the Trafford Centre in Greater Manchester closed due to the Summer Social event and for the use of motoring giant Tesla, customers were forced to find alternative spaces to leave their cars while shopping.The fight for a parking spot has led many shoppers to park on pavements, double lines, and inside disabled bays without permits, the Manchester Evening News reports.As a result of this, the shopping centre deployed parking wardens who have been handing out fines. Some customers took to social media to vent their frustration, while others complained to the shopping centre about the situation. A spokesperson for the Trafford Centre told Manchester Evening News: The Trafford Centre has a total of  car parks with  currently open, offering over , spaces. Even with the closure of Orient car parks ,  and , there are plenty of parking spaces available for visitors as well as public transport links We want to provide a safe and accessible environment for all our visitors. This means that certain areas of our car parks, such as pedestrian walkways and emergency exits, need to stay clear at all times. title: google wants fix your passwords
story: :root Google shares password checker tool after billions of accounts hacked - check yoursGoogle has urged people to use its free Chrome add-on Password Checkup to learn whether their credentials have been hacked by cyber crooks and sold on the webGoogle has urged internet users to install their free add-on Password Checkup to learntheir online credentials have been obtained and shared by cyber criminals Image: Anadolu Agency via Getty ImagesByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsGoogle is ready to fix your unsafe passwords as billions of online account passwords are leaked onto the internet. The search engine giant has created a free add-on that allows Chrome users to checktheir online credentials have been stolen. Password Checkup was first released in  as a free extension and itaposs designed to strengthen online security. By scanning known databases, it pinpoints usernames and passwords which hackers have lted from websites and made available to cyber criminals. Password Checkup urges users to switch up their access informationit has been leaked. Whenever you sign into a website, a pop up noties you of being one of over billion usernames and passwords that have been fraudulently obtained and advertised by hackers. In , Google Jenner Pullman explained the huge amount of usernames and passwords flagged during the applicationaposs scans.Since our launch, over , people have participated in our early experiment, she said. In the first month alone, we scanned million usernames and passwords and flagged over , as unsafe – .% of sign-ins scanned by the extension.  If you find that your credentials have been stolen and sold online, itaposs important to immediately change them. Even passwords, without usernames, can be an online safety hazard. Itaposs important to immediately change your log-in details to stay safe. Hackers purchase enormous databases of compromised passwords from ious sites because the letter combinations are often reused. By forcing long lists of known hacked passwords - rather than trying random letters or numbers - they are more likely to obtain account access. Hijackers routinely attempt to sign in to sites across the web with every credential exposed by a third-party breach, said Pullman. If you use strong, unique passwords for all your accounts, this risk disappears.The tool may pull from site breaches like the  LinkedIn hack, the Sun reports.The hack saw credentials of .million LinkedIn users being obtained and sold in lists online. title: its incredibly safe everything you
story: :root It’s incredibly safe - everything you need to know about vaccines for kidsHere’s how young people can get their Covid- vaccine – and go back to enjoying the things they loveAdvertorialByLaura Tait:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct Young people – who’ve missed out on so much over the past  months – are being offered their first dose of the Pfizer Covid- vaccine to protect themselves and the wider community from the virus. With last winter disrupted by lockdown, and young people missing so much school, college, time with friends and seeing grandparents, getting the vaccine will help make sure this year is a whole lot better. Not only does the vaccine protect young people against serious illness – almost  per cent of Covid patients admitted to hospital are unvaccinated – it also means they’re less likely to spread the virus to elderly family members. No more FOMO We’ve come a long way with the vaccination programme since those dark days of last winter. The Covid- vaccine has already saved more than , lives and prevented  million infections.Jabs are now being rolled out for the - age group, and more than  per cent of --year-olds have already had theirs. And getting the jab couldn’t be easier: schools and colleges are offering it through their immunisation programmes, while older teenagers can make an appointment through the online booking service at nhs.uk covidvaccination.If you’re a parent orof a --year-old, schools will ask for your consent before they receive the vaccine, and you can help --year-olds book their dose online. Then it’s one less thing for you to worry about – and they won’t need to worry about missing out on all those good times with family and friends.Fashion and lestyle influencer Arabella Daho , , is keen to book her vaccine appointment. “I think the vaccine is a great thing for everyone to have – it’s helping to keep us safe, she says. We have loads of events coming up such as Halloween and Christmas, and we don’t want to miss them. “On my digital s I’ve interviewed a few of the doctors who worked on the vaccine, talking about how safe it is, and why it’s important for everyone to get it. It was good to talk to them – I learned a lot, soanyone wants to see those videos or do research to help them feel better about getting the vaccine, I think they should. “Young people think they’re immune to everything, but we can actually be spreading Covid, especially to older people, who are more vulnerable. So getting jabbed helps communities and families get back to normal.” ‘All my kids have had their vaccines’ We asked GP and mum-of-three Dr Dawn Harper about what the vaccine means for young people… How do you feel about your kids being offered the vaccine  All my kids are in their s and they’ve all had their vaccines. I was very keen for them to get vaccinated as soon as they were eligible. If I had a -to--year-old I’d be putting them forward for the vaccine. We’ve been able to draw on global data several countries have already been offering the vaccine to --year-olds, and we have a lot of evidence to show that it’s safe for that age group. And while young people are less likely to become seriously ill with Covid, I am in total agreement with the chief medical officers concerning the impact on their mental health and their education, and also the possibility of long Covid. And, of course, we are only enjoying the relative freedoms we have today in the UK because of the vaccine programme. Without it, we’d still be in a lockdown. We need the vaccine to protect ourselves from Covid and long Covid, and also to protect our loved ones and our community. So I’m very keen for young people to come forward and have the vaccine. Did you have to persuade your children to have the jab  They were up for it. For me, lockdown was easier: I’m  and don’t mind walking my dog on my own, but I think young people really struggled missing out on their social lives.  What are the side effects of the vaccine in young people  The main one is perhaps a bit of soreness in the arm. I had a sore arm after my first vaccine but nothing at all after my second. It’s incredibly safe. I’m still amazed at how the researchers worked to get this to market as quickly as they did, running trials simultaneously without cutting safety corners. Long Covid is a worry for many parents. Will the vaccine protect young people against it  I have patients with long Covid. It is a horrible condition and there is evidence that the vaccine protects against this. We’re still on a very steep learning curve with long Covid. It’s unpredictable. We have fit young people who have been knocked sideways by it. The things that people talk to me about is the fatigue, the brain fog – I’ve got patients who are very intelligent academics who just can’tat work. Is the vaccine suitable for vegans and people with food allergies  It’s totally vegan-friendly and not a problem for those with allergies. What about those who are scared of needles  For the -to- age group, school nurses are well experienced in managing this. If you’re nervous you can ask to lie down. You can also buy over-the-counter cream to rub into your arm  minutes beforehand. I don’t even think I felt my second vaccine going in it’s such a tiny needle. For a moment of a sharp scratch, to know that you’re protected against Covid it’s well worth the trade-off. Has the vaccine been rigorously tested on the younger age group  Yes, I feel very confident about the science behind it. There’s been a lot of debate on risk vs benefit in dferent age groups. Young people are less likely to get seriously ill, but we need to weigh that against missed education, protection from long Covid and letting kids get out and about again so that we can help them with any mental health issues. If you come from a middle-class background where you’ve all got your own computers, home schooling was much easier thanyou’re all trying to share one screen, so it’s really important that we try to even out those dferences and get people back into the classroom.Last winter’s lockdown was so tough on young people’s mental health. Does the vaccine mean that things will be better this year  That wouldbe my hope. We’ll see messages coming out about meeting outside and ventilation I still wear a mask in the supermarket we have hand sanitiser in our bags and our cars, and I think that makes sense. But expanding the vaccine programme to include these younger people will mean that hopefully they can start to get back to some kind of normality. AGED  OR  If you have a teenager who hasn’t booked their vaccine yet, you can give them a helping hand so that they don’t get left behind – and protect the rest of the family from serious illness. Jabs can now be booked online at nhs.uk covidvaccination, or you can ask your GP or go to your nearest walk-in centre. PARENT OR CARER OF A --YEAR-OLD Offering young people the vaccine is essential to prevent them missing school and help make sure they can carry on doing the things they love with their friends and family. Everyone in this age group will be offered a first dose of the Pfizer vaccine through their school’s immunisation programme, which already administers the HPV and MMR vaccines. Parents and s will be asked for their consent via a form – andyou have any questions you can discuss them with the School Age Immunisation Service.

news uk-news mcdonalds-announces-big-changes-menus-"McDonalds launches first plant-based burgerByNeil ShawZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsMcDonald’s has been a staple fast-food chain since it launched in  – but big changes are on the horizon for the franchise.As part of the continued commitment to achieving net zero emissions by , McDonald’s UK  Ireland has launched the Plan for Change, which includes the steps the brand will take – both now and in the future – to support the planet and the communities it serves. One of the initiatives already underway is the creation of the first McDonald’s restaurant to be built to UK industry net zero emissions standards, Devon Live reports.The restaurant is being built in Shropshire, and when it opens next month, it will be a first for the UK industry and will act as a blueprint for future new builds. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Other additions in the Plan for Change include hiring a Nutrition Innovation Council who will work on developing more balanced menu options. The franchise recently launched the % vegan McPlant burger, and has plans to offer customers more vegan plant-based food and drink in the future. Paul Pomroy, Chief Executive of McDonald’s UK  Ireland, said: “McDonald’s has a long history of taking action where it really matters to the communities we serve. But we are at a moment now where we need to accelerate our ambition and work even harder to look after each other and the planet. “This new Plan for Change is not just our sustainability strategy, it’s our business priority. That means it isn’t a plan for one change, but for many – changes that together, with , restaurants, over , people, , British and Irish farmers and  million customers visiting every day, really will add up.” McDonald’s UKI has been attempting to reduce its impact on the planet for the last two decades, and the new Plan for Change hopes to build on the foundation the company has already made. The franchise has also been sourcing responsibly for over  years, with its menu already including % British and Irish beef, free range eggs, organic milk, RSPCA-assured pork, MSC-certied fish and Rainforest Alliance certied coffee. UK Net Zero Business Champion, Andrew Grfith, said: “Having an iconic brand like McDonald’s join the hundreds of businesses across the UK that have signed up to the UN’s Race to Net Zero campaign is an exciting milestone. “I hope businesses across the UK will be inspired by their ambitious initiatives, helping us all to build back greener.”To find out more on Plan for Change, click here. news uk-news orphaned-football-pioneer-british-armys-"Walter Tull: One of English footballs first ever black playersByKyle OSullivanTV Features Writer:,  Oct | commentsFew people will know the name Walter Tull, the inspirational footballer who became a true hero in more ways than one. Walter overcame adversity at every stage in his le then made the biggest sacrice of all to defend his country. Born in Folkestone, tragedy struck at a very young age when he lost his mother to breast cancer aged seven and then his dad passed away from heart disease just two years later. After losing both his parents, Walter and his brother Edward found themselves in a precarious and vulnerable position before being taken in by an orphanage in Bethnal Green. But there was more heartbreak to come when Walter was separated from his brother, who was adopted by a couple in Glasgow, leaving him alone. Walter was encouraged to pursue his love of football and started playing for amateur team Clapton FC, but soon he was spotted by the mighty Tottenham Hotspur, becoming one of English footballaposs first professional outfield players.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox. for a Mirror newsletter here. At the age of just -years-old, Tull signed for Spurs in  and soon found himself playing at White Hart Lane in front of crowds in the tens of thousands. Tottenhamaposs club historian, John Fennelly, explains that youngsters are fascinated by Tull and want to hear about his impact on the club and footballer in general. At the time we was about the best going, explains John. Somebody everyone wanted. We were delighted to get him here. He remains an incredible hero to us all hero. He is massive in our history. The legacy is amazing. Tull was subjected to horric racial abuse from the stands, with a newspaper reporting a cowardly attack on him during a match at Bristol City in . One newspaper report at the time described how, during a match at Bristol City in , a section of the crowd made a cowardly attack on him in language lower than Billingsgate. The reporter wrote: Let me tell those Bristol hooligans that Tull is so clean in mind and method as to be a model for all white men who play football. In point of ability,not actual achievement, Tull was the best forward on the field. When his career drted at Spurs following the abuse he suffered, he signed for Northampton Town in  for a substantial fee, but he gave up his football career at the outbreak of the First World War. Tullaposs le went down a very dferent path when he bravely enlisted with Middlesex Regiment, part of a aposFootballersapos Battalionapos that drew professional players from a range of clubs, just four months after the war began. news uk-news secret-gestures-show-exactly-meghan-"Kate Middleton can relax without Meghan claims LevinopinionByJudi James:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | comments  This week, new bombshell claims have emerged from royal author Andrew Morton about the nature of the relationship between Kate Middleton, the Duchess of Cambridge, and her sister-in-law Meghan Markle, the Duchess of Sussex. In the updated chapters of his unauthorised biography, Meghan: A Hollywood Princess, Morton explains how the two women, both thrust into the spotlight, were still getting to know each other when Meghan married Prince Harry. Here, body language expert Judi James takes a look back over Kate and Meghanaposs most photographed moments together to decode exactly when their friendship started to go sour - and unsurprisingly, how the public focused on them rather than the two royal brothers who were actually feuding... The relationship between these two royal women was built on three huge assumptions: firstly that they were naturally destined to be the closest of chums and allies, like Diana and Fergie were. Second that Meghan would enter the royal Firm at the same ‘level’ and state as Diana and Kate - i.e young, nervous, lacking in experience and in need of support, protection and hands-on coaching. And the third and biggest assumption was that William and Harry were the royal version of Jedward the very tightest of brothers who only needed a second we to turn their rather lopsided trio into a very idealistic ‘Fab Four’. Most of these assumptions were sexist. The phrase ‘The Merry Wives of Windsor’ might have been there waiting to be dusted off for use in some new headlines, but Diana and Fergie were pals before Fergie caught Andrew’s eye. Nobody ever expected Prince Philip and Anthony Armstrong-Jones to start dressing alike and skipping about together, or even Beatrice and Eugenie’s Eddo and Jack. And there was no way on this planet that a super-confident orced woman close to  with a career as a Hollywood actress, who was a very active and passionate speaker and campaigner, was ever going to need much hand-holding for this new role. If she did she had her husband on hand to fill her in about protocol and traditions. I believe Kate might even have been daunted by her new sister-in-law’s confidence, energy and professionalism. And of course Katewere also thrown into service as a smokescreen for a bigger and more unthinkable rt between the royal’s own version of Jedward.   The not-so Fab Four The stage appearance to launch the ‘Fab Four’ was gruesome. Kate and Meghan appeared to have been dressed from the same royal dressing-up box and seated in similar poses to make it look like the launch of a new royal doll for the ‘collection’.Meanwhile, the brothers were clearly already locked into some form of conflict - asked whether there had been disagreements between the couples during the planning of the launch, William’s Oh, yes was instantaneous and sounded heartfelt. Meghan dropped her head and placed a hand up in a cut-off gesture as though to hide her face, and the chuckles from Kate looked like nervous giggles.Kate was pregnant and sitting back in her chair, so although the idea of not having the ‘energy to bond’ with Meghan sounds like an odd sick note when most pregnant women continue their careers, let alone their social lives, she clearly can be unwell during her pregnancies.But even so, despite matching frocks there was already a sense from Meghan and Kate’s body language that Meghan’s experience, passion, drive and urgency for her cause was in contrast to Kate’s method of sitting back in her seat and watching the on-stage sibling tussle with a polite smile. Kate had spent years being marinated in royal rules, procedures and restrictions, so Meghan’s sense of purpose for a cause must have hit like a bath bomb. The post-wedding tears trip to Wimbledon, July Following rumours of tears during prep for Harry and Meghanaposs wedding, the two women put in a very ‘Diana and Fergie’ body language display at the tennis to signal publicly that all was well and suggest they really were the best of pals. I wouldn’t be too sure that a bit of ‘thank you’ jewellery sent out in a post run that included bridesmaids in the posh equivalent of a circular e-mail would be too telling, but the body language here did suggest an intention to log friendly rapport from both women, suggesting they were united in their messaging at least.There was a lot of eye contact and appreciative gestures from Kate here to signal she really was bonding with her sister-in-law, and the mirroring between the women did hint they were enjoying one of the key interests they shared.There was even some whispering and giggling together behind hands poses to help suggest they now had a more than just polite relationship and were beginning to look like genuine friends.Wives at war  The very sexist tone of two women being locked in some ‘cat fight’ continued though, despite the fact that we now know it was the men who had the real problem in their relationship.Kate and Meghan are two very dferent personalities, and dressing them the same was a pretty clichéd way of insulting two successful women - but I’m pretty sure they would have happily performed many years of politely smiling PDAs had the brothers not been locked in their rt.The balcony poses and photos of the two women at more formal events might have looked iconic in terms of defining a rt, but the context is slightly wrong. Perhaps because of William and Harry’s spat the royal pecking order was suddenly more defined at these events, and Harry and Meghan always seemed to be pushed back into the chorus line behind William and Kate. Where the two women appear to be standing together wearing icy expressions and ignoring each other, they were in fact standing one behind the other, so happy chats would have been dficult. At this point the tension on Harry’s face and the haunted expression in his eyes told all the story of what was about to come but attention was of course focused on the two women at the time. Even at the first Commemoration service, it was Kate and Meghan’s body language together that soaked up all the interest. Here they stood together in mirrored poses, wearing polite smiles, but it was their husbands wearing the haunted eye expressions while patently ignoring each other.The Christmas  walk to church threw up the kind of ‘denial’ body language we normally only see from politicians or Strictly contestants who have cheated on their wives. Kate took up the challenge to signal all was truly happy between herself and Meghan in what was obviously a set piece for the cameras. While William and Harry walked on the outside, yet again free from all the interest and speculation of a rt, it was up to Kate to step across to Meghan to chat and smile to suggest a relaxed and spontaneous moment of friendship. Meghan kept her arm linked into Harry’s and her bag as a barrier between herself and Kate. The Duchess of Cambridge was pregnant with Prince Louis at the time but solo, unaided walking was surely still on the menu, although she did turn her head and smile to form an appealing-looking pose for the press.It was during the very last outing for the now not-so Fab Four that the tension was much more obvious and palpable. A mutual gloom appeared to settle over William and Kate as they arrived to take their seats in the pews in front of Harry and Meghan.Even Kate’s signature smile had vanished on what was Harry and Meghan’s last gig before they fled to the arms of Oprah.We didn’t get to seeMeghan’s bravely polite smiles of greeting were ed by her sister and brother-in-law, but the way her beaming smile dropped like a brick suggested they were not. Cara Donovan, , was a wedding guest at Country House Weddings Ltdaposs venue Leez Priory - a th Century Tudor mansion near Chelmsford, Essex. The manor, which is nestled in  acres of parkland, has been repeatedly voted the UKaposs Best Wedding Venue. The special needs teacher is now suing the company in charge of the reception for £, after slipping and breaking her elbow on their state-of-the-art twinkling dancefloor in September . The -year-oldaposs elbow was badly broken and she was left with constant arm pain - which still impacts all areas of her everyday le.  Despite three operations, Caraaposs arm says she is still in agony, and she has been unable toto teach at school. Country House Weddings Ltd, which owns Leez Priory, were told by the suppliers of the high-tech dancefloor that it would be a slip-hazarddrinks were spilled on it, according to documents filed at the High Court. But nothing was done to prevent guests taking liquid on the dancefloor and the companyaposs adverts even showed photos of people drinking and dancing, Caraaposs lawyers claim. During the evening guests would go onto the dancefloor - either to cross it or to dance - holding glasses of drink and occasionally spilling drink onto the dancefloor, says her barrister, Philip Goddard.  The dance floor became wet with patches of spilt drink. The danceflooraposs underfloor lights made it dficult for those on the dancefloor to see spilt liquid on the surface. At about pm, the claimant went onto the floor to dance. She slipped in the spilt drink, fell and fractured her right, dominant, arm. Doctors have performed three surgeries on Caraaposs broken arm, but none have healed her permanent pain and weakness, the lawyer claims. The mother-of-two, from Romford, canapost write, drive, use a keyboard, or handle any two-handed machinery after her injury. She would like toto teaching, but is inhibited by the injury, says Mr Goddard. A fourth operation may be needed to remove a bone fragment, but its present condition is unlikely to improve. Cara blames Country House Weddings Ltd for her injury and the impact it has had on her le. She claims the company didnapost follow the supplieraposs no drinks warning and failed to enforce it by putting staff at suitable locations around the venue. Tables were also placed at the danceflooraposs edge, which Cara claims encouraged people to drink and dance. Staff also failed to move guests to mop up spilled drinks, it is claimed. Country House Weddings Ltdaposs defence was not available from the court. Caraaposs claim has not yet been tested in evidence by a judge.
