title: letter-week-not-impressed-number-campervans-north-berwick-seafront
story: This leaves no parking for anyone driving down there at the weekend andyou want to go onto the sand at the bottom of the steps by the water treatment plant, you have to cut through tables and chairs set up for their free holiday.Last weekend, there were  units parked up in a fairly small area, yet, being a campervan owner, I am fully aware that on a caravan site they have to keep you six metres apart to comply with fire regulations.One hopes East Lothian Council intervenes before something terrible happens.The motorhomes are often less than one metre apart, with fire pits and campfires set up each evening.On a visit to Ruby Bay in Fe recently, they had a large parking area for about  vehicles with seven designated for overnight parking on a first-come, first-served basis. This ensures that anyone staying overnight has sufficient space and seems like a sensible and proactive measure.The parking in Fe also had a public toilet: I can only hope that all of the campers in North Berwick are taking all of the contents of their toilet cassette and dirty dishwater home to be emptied there and that nothing is being dumped at the beach.We have a sign displayed here stating lsquoNo Overnight Parkingrsquo but this is a token gesture, as all motorhome owners know that this is not legally enforceable.I would like to see a change being made to ensure that the area is safe and for use by overnight tourists, day tourists and locals.Name and address suppliedAn East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoWorking with our partners, we continue to actively consider action to support the responsible use of public land. This is important given the popularity of lsquostaycationsrsquo and the large number of visitors coming to East Lothian. In the meantime, we would encourage anyone who encounters vehicles parked in an unsafe way on the public road to make the authorities aware by contacting the police on .

title: families-remember-ancestors-lost-lives-sea-130-years-ago
story: Cousins and former pupils of Musselburgh Grammar School Jim Ritchie Johnston, , a Musselburgh resident, and Stuart Ritchie, , who now lives in Markinch, Fe, met at Fisherrow Harbour to remember their great grandfather James Ritchie.He drowned at the age of  after Star of the East was shipwrecked at the entrance to Lowestoft Harbour on November , , after the crew of eight set off from Fisherrow on September  that year.They were joined at a poignant family harbourside gathering by Mr Johnstonrsquos son Keith, a Musselburgh resident, and Mr Ritchiersquos sons Scottand Craig .Musselburgh resident Peter Millarrsquos great grandfatherrsquos brother John Williamson, a -year-old fisherman, also lost his le in the fishing tragedy.The boatrsquos skipper Walter Brown, aged , drowned as did his sons Walter, aged , and -year-old James, Alexander Brown, , and Robert Dickson, .The sole survivor of the tragedy was James Bonthron who reportedly clung to a piece of wreckage and was deaf from that time on.Simon Fairnie, of Musselburgh Museum, has researched the loss of The Star.He said: ldquoMany fishermen were lost at sea in the old days of sailing: one reason being that the herring fishing season occurred in early autumn and early winter when storms and gales were frequent.The  season had been patchy, with catches from September disappointing and the men of the Star of the East ndash a Fie which was a boat popular with the Fisherrow men ndash decided to try their luck further south.On November , explained Mr Fairnie, the fishing boat left Lowestoft for the fishing grounds and hauled about  barrels of herring before sailing for port at midnight.He said: ldquoBy .am a gale had reached its height and a wary approach was made to harbour.ldquoLowestoft in those days was regarded as dangerous to navigate. There were two lighthouses at the harbour entrance: one on a northern clf and the other to the south. These were intended to guide vessels through the portrsquos channel which had dangerous sand banks on either side.ldquoBut heavy rain prevented The Starrsquos crew from seeing the lights properly and there was a breakwater to be avoided before the harbour could be taken.ldquoOn entering the port, a huge wave bore down on the boat, threatening to throw it onto the breakwater.ldquoThe crew took what evasive action they could but, sadly, the boat was dashed against the masonry pier with such force that she quickly broke up with the tragic loss of all the crew but one.An active search was made but none of the bodies were reportedly found at that time.Almost five months later, the body of the skipper was found by fisherman William Cross, washed ashore at Dunwich, on March , .Newspapers reported at the time of memorial services being held in Musselburgh and visits made to grief-stricken families by the provost.Stuart Ritchie said it was believed that the skipperrsquos body was the only one found.He said: ldquoAfter a good deal of searching over a period of time, recently I found my great grandfatherrsquos death certicate. I feel very sad that, apparently, Jamesrsquos body was never found so a funeral may never have taken place.But he added: ldquoIt is good that the descendants are meeting up.ldquoIt would be even betterthe wider community in the Musselburgh Fisherrow area was made aware of this heritage and perhaps the local authority could do a bit to help here.He felt a lasting memorial to the crew of Star of the East at Fisherrow Harbour would be a fitting tribute to them.Mr Johnston added: ldquoAttending our harbour ceremony felt like stepping back into the past to remember and honour, not only James Ritchie and the other brave men of The Star who lost their lives, but also to allow us today to pay tribute to every family within the Fisherrow fishing community for the important contribution it has made to the economy and history of Musselburgh over many years.Walter Brown jnrrsquos great grandson Walter Moffat, , who lives in Toronto, Canada, visited the skipper Walter Brown snrrsquos grave at Dunwich in early  where a memorial stone had been placed by his widow Jane lsquoBonthronrsquo Brown.He said his ancestor was seen by commanding everyone to ldquosave themselves as he held the mast going down with the ship.ldquoCoincidentally, Walter Brown jnr forgot to take his bible on that trip ndash I have it at home, said his descendant who is the grandson of Walter Brown, the son of Walter Brown jr and Elizabeth Brown , who was just one when his father died in the shipwreck.The Scottish Fisheries Museum at Anstruther is planning to mark the th anniversary of the loss of The Star at its annual memorial service in the museumrsquos Memorial Room in October. The ceremony is organised in conjunction with the Fishermenrsquos Mission and is open to relatives of those lost.The names of the crew of The Star who died also look set to be listed in the museumrsquos memorial book which records the names of fishermen lost at sea prior to . Those from  onwards are recorded on brass plaques on the walls.Curator Linda Fitzpatrick said: ldquoThe entries are made at the request of family members and can reflect iniduals or entire crews of boats. They are not a complete record of all losses.ldquoThis ensures that we have the details correct and that we take account of family sensitivities.She added: The dangers of le at sea are all too well known and, often, the tragedy of a sinking was compounded by the fact that the men sailed with their relatives so that a father, husband, brother and son could be lost in a single incident.

title: tims-tales-shipwrecked-viking-andrews-legacy
story: I donrsquot remember the date I first saw this picture , but I remember the impact it had on me. It captures an imagined moment in which the legendary Viking Althamer sails along the coast of the Firth of Forth.It is the work of Andrew Hillhouse, an artist who sadly died in  at the young age of . I wish I had been wise enough to seek him out and talk with him about history and his art when Irsquod had the opportunity.His widow Vicky has told me of his modesty, that he wouldnrsquot call himself an artist because he was a working man with a job to pay the bills. He once wrote that he was ldquostill just a guy who likes to doodle in his spare time.Some doodles! His art is stunning: full of historical detail and atmosphere, and his work portrays many aspects of Scottish history, which was one of Andrewrsquos passions.His website has many more examples of his art, with short explanations to accompany them.He grew up in Prestonpans and knew the local legend of the townrsquos beginnings that it was founded by a Viking traveller named Althamer, who was shipwrecked with his crew on its rocky shore after a ferocious storm about a thousand years ago in the th century.As Andrew himself wrote: ldquoStories from this period are very dficult to very, but the legend persists to this dayhellip the image shows Althamerrsquos ship passing Bass Rock as the sun sets on the evening before their hard landing on Scotlandrsquos shores.But although this is a legend and not history, we do know that there was Viking activity around East Lothianrsquos shores in the th century. For example, it is recorded that the Norse king of Dublin, Olaf Guthfrithson, raided Tyninghame in AD and died soon afterwards.And perhaps he lies buried there. In , the farmer at Auldhame, Mr Dale, ploughed up bones. An archaeological dig took place and an Anglo Saxon monastery was revealed. A male skeleton was discovered buried there with items that identy him as being a high-ranking Norse warrior.It canrsquot be said for sure the skeleton was the remains of King Olaf himself. But itrsquos a fascinating possibility.The thing is, we have tiny historical glimpses of this time, with archaeology sometimes adding to our knowledge while also sometimes adding to the intrigue.To this, we can add the stories, told down the generations, at the firesides of the common folk. These stories often had their origin in an account of someonersquos experience, or a memory of an event, which then evolved to become part of folklore and legend.Since the story of Althamerrsquos arrival was set in a time of extensive Norse and Danish settlement, the idea of Prestonpans being founded by a shipwrecked Viking is not entirely fancul. There was, after all, a Viking settlement a few miles down the coast at Luffness, by Aberlady Bay.So Andrewrsquos image of Althamer and his crew sailing to their fate along the East Lothian coast is now part of the telling of this legend.The story lit my imagination and interest in history when I was a youngster growing up in Prestonpans. It still does.Irsquove often stood on its shore in a storm to watch the waves crash against the rocks in a rage, and see in my mindrsquos eye the Viking longboat being smashed.There is so much in this picture for you to discover, and it speaks more words than I can write.So I will leave it with you.It is produced here with thanks from Vicky Hillhouse, who gave her permission to use it on this page.But she has also kindly given permission for its use by local schoolchildren, who are now the younger custodians of the legend.

title: sight-loss-support-a-blessing-prestonpans-resident-agnes-78
story: Agnes Stevenson, , of Grant Road, received her age-related macular degeneration diagnosis in  when she was a full-time carer for husband Tom, who had dementia and passed away last year.Struggling with the impact of her sight loss, Agnes reached out to the charity Sight Scotland through its newly launched telephone support line ndash she has since praised the community service for helping her feel less alone.The Sight Scotland Support Line, launched across Edinburgh and the Lothians in January as part of the newly formed Family Wellbeing Service which launched last Wednesday, offers people with sight loss and their families someone to turn to for information, advice and support.The retired bookkeeper said: ldquoI didnrsquot know anything about macular degeneration.ldquoWhen I was told I had it, I was devastated.ldquoAt that time, I got no information at all.ldquoIt was a huge shock. If I had had support at an earlier point following my diagnosis, I donrsquot think I would have gone into such a depression.ldquoWhen you hear that your sight is going, you think: lsquoWhat am I going to do  How am I going to manage rsquoldquoYou canrsquot sleep for thinking about how yoursquore going to cope.ldquoI had given up completely. It made me quite depressed, thinking that nothing  could help with my sight.ldquoWhen I contacted Sight Scotland, Irsquod just thought: lsquoI have to do something. I cannot accept this.rsquoldquoThis is the first time I feel I have some support now. There was somebody there who would listen to me. Itrsquos been a blessing.Sight Scotlandrsquos Family Wellbeing Service team has provided emotional support to Agnes as she adapts to le with sight loss, including aiding her in regaining her much-loved sewing hobby.In addition to the telephone service, Sight Scotlandrsquos Family Wellbeing Service also provides the option of face-to-face home visits for people based in East Lothian.The Tranent-born resident said: ldquoOne of the Sight Scotland community workers, Debbie McGregor, has introduced me to dferent options and given me so much confidence. Shersquos been helping me with magniers and explaining how that can help. I see a future for myself and that is thanks to Sight Scotland.ldquoThere must be hundreds of people like me. The Sight Scotland Support Line can be a huge help for people impacted by sight loss.ldquoThere is somebody there for you. You donrsquot need to be alone.Sight Scotlandrsquos latest findings show out of  visually impaired people, more than  per cent said they had not had enough information about where to access support after this diagnosis.More than  per cent said it was important to provide more support to family members and carers.Mark OrsquoDonnell, chief executive of Sight Scotland and Sight Scotland Veterans, said: ldquoWe are proud to officially launch the Sight Scotland Support Line nationally. This new telephone service is there for anyone impacted by visual impairment so that no one in Scotland has to struggle with sight loss alone.People impacted by sight loss can call the Sight Scotland Support Line on   , Monday to Friday, am-pm, or visit SightScotland.org.uk for more information.

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-1996-1971-1921
story: lsquoFEAR of cuts in hospital servicesrsquo was front page news in the East Lothian Courier on September , .Fears that local hospital services could be under threat to release cash for new hospital building in Edinburgh have led to a top-level meeting with Health Minister Lord James Douglas-Hamilton.Labour MP John Home Robertson, local councillors and health officials say they are seriously concerned by reports that, in the run-up to using private finance, Lothian Health Board will run down services such as day surgery at Roodlands Hospital, Haddington, where the casualty unit has already been withdrawn.And the MP promised ldquofierce resistancecuts to vital services were proposed.He was joined by East Lothian Councilrsquos social work chairman David Costello and Roodlands consultant Dr George Rhind for last weekrsquos meeting with Lord James at the Scottish Office.Mr Home Robertson demanded assurances about plans for the new Royal Infirmary at Little France as well as existing hospital services in East Lothian.lsquoBILLY the beer drinking budgie diesrsquo, The Haddingtonshire Courier of October ,  sadly reported!Regulars at the Plough Tavern, Haddington, were disappointed to find an empty cage in the bar last week. Billy the budgie had died.Billy, the chirpy green budgie, who had been the centre of attention in the bar during the past five years, used to delight customers with his antics.Billy, who never tasted water for eight years, could often be seen having a sip of beer from customersrsquo glasses. But he never touched spirits.ldquoHe preferred beer, said his owner, Mr Bill Reid, the proprietor of the Tavern, who used to breed budgerigars.ldquoMy we, Rena, and I had Billy since he hatched from an egg ndash  years ago.North Berwick High Schoolrsquos war memorial was unveiled, said The Haddingtonshire Courier of September , .On Friday, the memorial which has been placed in the High School was unveiled by Miss Lucy Hope, in the presence of a large gathering of present and former pupils, and relatives and friends of those whose names appear on the roll of honour.Among those present with Miss Hope and the Rectorwere:- Rev. James Davidson and Mr R Miller, members of the Education Authority Mr R. D. Robertson, M.A. B.Sc., Executive Officer of the Authority Dr Waddell, Provost Farquharson, Mr A D Wallace and Mr Graham, of the School Management Committee.

title: pick-pumpkin-farm-near-athelstaneford
story: Kilduff Farm, near Athelstaneford, is home to East Lothianrsquos well-loved pumpkin patch, specialising in culinary pumpkins as well as traditional Hallowersquoen ieties.Lucy and Russell Calder, from North Berwick, took over the arable farm from Russellrsquos grandfather in  ndash the farm has been in the Calder family since .They are excited to welcome new and old faces from East Lothian and beyond to pick their own homegrown pumpkins between October  and  at their fourth annual pumpkin festival.The festival is a family affair, as Lucy and Russell were assisted by children Maisie, , Louisa, nine, and Charlie, five, in planting , pumpkin seeds in April.Following a successful period of being cared for in the polytunnels at Kilduff Farm, the pumpkin plants were planted in two patches at the start of June.As well as some of the more commonly known ieties, including Crown Prince, Knuckle Head and the popular Tractor iety, the Calders are trialling some new pumpkin ieties this year, with the likes of Racer, Orange Smoothie and Polar Bear giving more choice for ghostly carving.Lucy said: ldquoA huge amount of planning goes on behind the scenes to prepare for our pumpkin festival and we spend a lot of time praying to the weather gods.ldquoThankfully, this yearrsquos crop is looking really promising and we are so looking forward to sharing our hard work and excitement with lots of people this year.ldquoAfter the year we have all had, we want to add a real festival vibe to The Patch with a few added extras to pack a bit of a punch.The family hope to educate and inspire children about Scottish-grown food.Lucy added: ldquoWersquore really passionate about Scottish farming and highlighting the work which goes on behind the scenes.ldquoPumpkins are just one of many crops we grow but it is a great one to hook childrenrsquos interest and educate them about how food grows and how to cook with pumpkins.ldquoThis is something in which we invest a huge amount of thought with the culinary ieties we grow.ldquoPumpkins are nutritious, delicious and versatile, and we want to reduce the food waste which comes with each Hallowersquoen. Wersquove created a bank of recipes which we hope will inspire people to get creative in the kitchen with their pumpkins.The annual pumpkin festival has been open to the public since  and the Calder family have grown more than , pumpkins this year.Visitors can also visit the pumpkin house for family photos, explore the straw bale maze and look at the resident scarecrows.The Patch remained open to the public last year, but Covid restrictions meant visitor numbers were restricted.This year, food and drink from local businesses Drt and FieldFireFork, Kilduff-grown pumpkins and apples will feature on a menu on offer to visitors. Numbers will be managed in accordance to Covid guidelines.For more information or to book, visit kilduff

title: tesco-fresh-bid-avoid-paying-400k-interest-contributions-schooling-musselburgh
story: The food chain is appealing to Scottish Ministers to step in after East Lothian Council billed it four months afterconstruction started on  new homes on land formerly owned by the firm.Tesco had argued that it no longer had to pay the pound, educationcontribution tied to the new housing as it was no longer the owner of the land.But it lost its argument and an appeal against the decision was ruled lsquounlawfulrsquo.After being told it had to pay the bill, Tesco then applied to change the terms of the repaymentso it did not have to pay until the last house was completed rather than at the start of the development as previously agreed.The request was refused by the local authority, which now wants the bill paid with interest backdated to last year.The supermarket chain has now lodged an appeal with Scottish Ministers, asking them to overturn the councilrsquos decision so it can pay the bill at the end of the development and avoid the interest.East Lothian Council has argued that Tesco is getting off lightly after the deal over the land at its former store site at Olivebank was signed  years ago.They said thata similar deal was struck today, the contribution request would be closer to pound,.And they warned that a delay to the payment being made could ldquosignicantly impact ongoing projects to provide a new secondary school in Wallyford and extend Musselburgh Grammar School.Under planning legislation, local authorities can ask housing developers to pay a proportion of money towards schooling to counteract the additional number of families moving into their homes.Appealing against paying the contribution, Tesco argued: ldquoThis transactiontook place over a decade ago and the land of the residential developmentsite is not owned by Tesco.Rejecting Tescorsquos application, planning officers warned that Tesco was liable for interest rates of four per cent above the Bank of Scotland rate on the outstanding payment and the longer they took to pay, the more the value of the contribution was eroded by cost increases.They added that it would set a precedent for future infrastructure contributions which could put them at risk.The appeal has been lodged with the Scottish GovernmentReporters.

title: another-8-000-trees-planted-butterdean-wood
story: Woodland Trust Scotland is extending Butterdean Wood, near Gladsmuir, as part of a -year partnership to plant trees and create new woods across the country.Two open fields have been acquired which will add . hectares to the existing . hectares, enabling , more trees to be planted over the next  months.The community is now being asked to help choose a name for the new extension ndash and there are opportunities to go along to help plant it.Potential names for the extension are: Butterdean Coille Darach, Butterdean Brocksden, Butterdean Paddock, Butterdean Fauld, Butterdean Boar Copse and Butterdean Wolf Copse.Alastair Seaman, Woodland Trust Scotland director, said: ldquoIt will be a marvellous haven for people and wildle but also a carbon store to help in the fight against climate change.The native trees will be planted from autumn through to  with the help of Bank of Scotland colleagues, local schoolchildren and the community.The trees have the potential to absorb up to , tonnes of carbon in their letime.To vote on a name for the new extention, visit emea.focusvision survey selfserve  Voting closes on October .Butterdean Coille Darach is Gaelic for Butterdean Oak Wood Butterdean Brocksden reflects a large and long-established badger sett nearby Butterdean Paddock and Butterdean Fauld acknowledges the ground has been used to graze horses in the past Butterdean Boar Copse and Wolf Copse reflect that boars and wolves were once native to the area.

title: jacquie-bell-elected-chair-dunbar-east-linton-area-partnership
story: Jacquie Bell has succeeded George Robertson, who announced last year that he would be stepping down from Dunbar and East Linton Area Partnership .The group, which is led by community volunteers, aims to make a dference locally and address the impacts of poverty.Mrs Bell, who is also secretary of Dunbar Community Council, was looking forward to officially taking on the role from next month.She said: ldquoI want to thank DELAP for electing me as their new community chairperson.ldquoI have been active as a local community volunteer for many years, including working closely with George on co-ordinating the local response to Covid.ldquoI am committed to helping to make Dunbar and East Linton the best it can be for local residents.ldquoI am excited to be taking on the new role and wish to do so in an inclusive way.ldquoI want to ensure that the area partnership hears voices and views from all parts of the ward to ensure that it works to make a dference to the lives of everyone in both Dunbar town and the smaller settlements.Mrs Bell, who has lived in Belhaven since , previously worked as a social worker and has been an active member of the area partnership since it was established.She has been the grouprsquos vice-chairwoman since  and a member of Dunbarrsquos community council for more than  years.She also served as a Liberal Democrat councillor representing the Dunbar and East Linton ward on East Lothian Council from  to .Now, she is looking to build on the work of Mr Robertson, who was chairman of DELAP for three years.During that time, he has overseen a number of projects, including the repainting of some of the building facades on Dunbar High Street, the installation of benches around the area, as well as improvements to some village facilities in Tyninghame, West Barns and Belhaven.During the pandemic, he played a leading role in bringing volunteers together and supported a number of initiatives to help those affected by Covid-.Led by community volunteers, Dunbar and East Linton is one of six area partnerships which receive funding from East Lothian Council to identy local priorities and help reduce inequalities.It is supported by East Lothian Councilrsquos connected communities service, which promotes and delivers the councilrsquos community empowerment aims ndash working collaboratively with local communities, other council services, community planning partners such as Police Scotland, NHS, third-sector and community organisations ndash to make a dference locally and address the impacts of poverty.Mr Robertson said: ldquoI am very proud to have been associated with DELAP and all of the positive outcomes we have achieved for our communities, particularly during the past  months of the pandemic.ldquoWe have supported a number of great community initiatives, including food provisions such as the lsquomeals on wheelsrsquo delivery service for people who were shielding.ldquoAs well as providing a cooked meal, this helped tackle social isolation for those unable to see friends and family due to lockdown.ldquoAll across the Dunbar and East Linton area we have seen many improvements through the hard title: looking-back-sir-john-cope-house-cockenzie
story: He became an army officer and distinguished himself in ious European engagements.In , Cope was promoted to lieutenant-general and, just before the  Rising, he was appointed military commander in Scotland.After Prince Charles and his men had landed at Eriskay, Cope withdrew to Inverness, leaving Edinburgh exposed.The Prince lost no time before he entered the Capital in triumph with his army of Highlanders, rough types who were capable of anything.After Cope had loaded his troops onto ships at Aberdeen and sailed for Dunbar, the two armies met at Prestonpans on September , .Many of Copersquos troops were inexperienced recruits and his officers were a feeble lot.Early the following morning, when the Highlanders charged, Copersquos dragoons fled in panic, leaving the infantry exposed.Had the humane Prince and his officers not interceded, a bloodbath might well have have ensued, with no prisoners taken.The craven Cope fled to Berwick-upon-Tweed with some of his officers and a rabble of surviving soldiers.He faced a court martial but was exonerated, the cowardly conduct of the soldiers being blamed for everything.He obtained another appointment as Governor of Limerick but never held an independent field command again.There was an early rumour among the Scottish victors that Sir John Cope had overslept on the morning of the battle although it inspired the rousing bagpipe tune Hey, Johnnie Cope, Are Ye Waking Yet , that version of events is not true.Then there was a story that although Prince Charles had spent the night before the battle on duty with his men, Cope had slept at comfortable quarters in Cockenzie.This tale was reported by the Edinburgh historian Robert Chambers as early as , although Copersquos  biographer Sir Robert Cadell found it yet another calumny: in spite of the assertions of Chambers and others, Cope had slept with his troops on the battlefield, as veried by the Culloden Papers and the Proceedings of Copersquos court martial.In his  biography of Prince Charles, the mischievous W. Drummond Norie lsquoimprovedrsquo the old legend further, claiming that Cope had been spending the night at a comfortable house in Cockenzie, nowadays referred to as the lsquoInk Bottlersquo and pictured in his book. This story was widely believed at the time.On June , , The Scotsman newspaper wrote that: ldquoIn Cockenzie several properties have been medically condemned and after a long allowance of time these have been closed amongst others portions of the historic Ink Bottle [Copersquos House].But the old house survived this crisis, however, being featured and photographed in the Edinburgh Evening News of August , , as a curious reminder of the hapless English generalrsquos efforts in the Battle of Prestonpans.The Cockenzie and Port Seton chronicler Dr R. Turner, writing in , rightly puts the curiously shaped old Ink Bottle house in or near Cope Lane in Port Seton, not far from the Old Parish Church Manse, adding that it had recently been demolished.I have been snooping round these parts to very this fact: the Ink Bottle is no longer standing, having fallen victim to the vandals of the s.Some historical revisionists from south of the Border have belatedly tried to save Sir John Copersquos reputation: the expedition to Inverness was caused by the bad advice he was given by some Scottish renegade noblemen, and the defeat at Prestonpans was wholly due to the poor quality of the soldiery.As we know, the story of him deserting his troops the morning of the battle is not true, but he did leave his military chest containing his papers and pound, for soldierrsquos pay under a staircase at Cockenzie House, where it was gleefully seized by the Prince and his men.It had been Copersquos decision to leave Edinburgh exposed, and it had been his responsibility to make sure the troops were properly trained and ably officered.The headlong flight to Berwick-upon-Tweed does not inspire confidence either, since it had been his duty to try his utmost to rally the troops, even at the cost of his own le.As a result of Sir John Cope being recalled, the Auld Enemy made sure that more canny officers, and tougher soldiers recalled from the Continent, were brought to Scotland to suppress the Rising: this target was achieved, just as planned, by lsquoButcherrsquo Cumberland at Culloden in .

title: charity-golf-day-musselburgh-golf-club-raises-1-000-maggies
story: Each year, players gather at Musselburgh Golf Club at Monktonhall to play for the Norrie Hosie Friday Cup.The tournament has grown from small beginnings, when local man NormanHosie Senior, from Stoneybank, began playing with friends back in the s.He donated a trophy for the match, the organisation of which has been taken over by his son Norrie Junior, from Wallyford, who has attracted sponsors for the event, which raises hundreds of pounds for charity each year, including Alzheimer Scotland, Royal Hospital for Children  Young People, and Changes, a Musselburgh-based community health project.This year, Mr Hosie Jnr decided to donate the money to Maggiersquos Edinburgh at the Western General Hospital, which helped him and his we Shirley after her breast cancer diagnosis last November.About  golfers took part in the recent competition, which was won by Alister Gray and raised pound for the charity. Since then, more donations have been forthcoming, taking the total to pound,.Norman said that Shirley underwent surgery in January and, after a three-week recovery period, she started four months of chemotherapy. After another three-week break, she began a month of radiotherapy.ldquoThis all finished in July this year and my we still has three years of bone treatments to do, one every six months, Norman said.ldquoShirley is now recovering from it all and doing well but has a long way to go before getting the all clear. All this was done through this yearrsquos Covid- pandemic and what great help and support came from the surgeons, nurses and consultants from the Western General Hospital. We canrsquot thank them enough.ldquoWe were told to go to visit Maggiersquos for further help and support as we started the process of chemotherapy and radiotherapy. They bent backwards to help us, offering one to one talks with us together and separately. They were so good at understanding what we were going through. We cannot praise the support specialists enough. As soon as we walked in the door of Maggiersquos, we were made so welcome ndash it was like we had known them for years.ldquoI think going to Maggiersquos did help face your fears. They listened to you and understood how you were feeling. They said it was normal to have bad days but not to beat yourself up when you had days like that. Maggiersquos gave you that sense of understanding what you were going through. They were so helpful, it is a place to go to for support, help, understanding and calm.ldquoI would say to anyone going through anything similar that you go to Maggiersquos for support, help and professional advice. They are so warm and welcoming to the patients and their families.He also thanked Musselburgh Golf Club for its organisation of the charity day and the sponsors, including Tony Rayfield, of Edinburgh Hometyre, and David McKay, from Direct Gardens.Mark Cooper, fundraising manger at Maggiersquos Edinburgh, said: ldquoEveryone at Maggiersquos is hugely appreciative to Norman and his friends for choosing to support Maggiersquos Edinburgh at their annual charity golf day.ldquoWe rely entirely on voluntary donations to operate and the demand for our services and complexity of the work we do has increase signicantly over the past  months.

title: auction-big-hare-trail-statues-raises-115-000-leuchie-house
story: The grand auction of the  sculptures took place at the towns Marine Hotel to raise money for the respite care centre on the outskirts of North Berwick.The hares, commissioned to mark Leuchiersquos th anniversary as an independent charity, delighted people of all ages as part of the The Big Hare Trail this summer.And they were in high demand as generous bidders dug deep to support the work of Leuchie, which provides expert care and a holiday experience to people affected by neurological conditions such as MS, stroke and MND.One of the most popular giant statues was lsquoHare Tae Golfrsquo, which was found at the West Links, having earlier made a cameo at The Renaissance during the Scottish Open.Chris Rutterfordrsquos eye-catching creation was sold for pound, ndash one of five hares that went to new homes for five-figure bids.As well as the  hares that featured on this yearrsquos trail, a blank lsquoMystery Harersquo went under the hammer at the end of the auction for pound,, and one of the artists will complete a bespoke edition for the successful bidder.Broadcaster Glenn Campbell, host for the evening, said: ldquoCongratulations to all the lucky bidders and Leuchie has asked me to pass on a very sincere thank you for your support."To put this into perspective, this funding could pay the salaries of four specialist nurses for an entire calendar year.Thanking the local businesses who sponsored the hares, he added: ldquoThis all began with a leap of faith that was taken by a number of businesses and organisations to sponsor The Big Hare Trail in the midst of a pandemic."Without these sponsors, this event would not have been possible."Stephen Pearson, chair of Leuchie House, said: ldquoThe hare trail has also been an ambitious project and, as we celebrate our th birthday this year, the board and the team are ambitious to do more, for more people, in the years ahead.Graeme Scougall, from Paisley, a regular guest at Leuchie, was one of the guests of honour on the night. Graeme was diagnosed with MS six years ago at the age of .Lana Bambridge, Leuchiersquos head of fundraising and development, said: ldquoWersquore pleased that the hares have captured the hearts of the local community."Every penny raised from the auction will help us to continue to support families who are in desperate need of a break from caring, especially in the wake of the pandemic.

title: nicola-sturgeon-covid-update-today-time-watch
story: The Scottish government came under fire when people reported problems using the NHSScotland Covid Status App after its release on Thursday.Vaccine passports is just one of a number of changes introduced over the past seven days, with new travels rules coming into effect from Monday.Scotland announced last month that it would maintain a four nation approach to travel despite initial hesitancy to do so.It means that the same rules apply to international travel wherever in the UK you are visiting.Heres everything you need to know about todays update including what the first minister might say...Nicola Sturgeons Covid update will take place today at around :pm.The exact timing of the announcement will depend on the previous three items on the agenda running to time.You can watch the first ministers Covid update on Scottish ParliamentTV.Alternatively it will be streamed live on the Scottish governments social media s and the SNP will live tweet the statement.The briefing will also be broadcast live on the BBC Scotland channel from :pm.The first minister will as always provide an update on the figures, as well as the progress in vaccination.She is als likely to touch on the implementation of the vaccine passport scheme and perhaps the new status app.Following Nicola Sturgeons statement there will be a ministerial update on the Covid Recovery Strategy, so the first minister may indicate in her speech what this strategy may include.

title: north-berwick-home-branded-grand-designs-experiment-approved
story: Architect Robin Sutherland saw his vision of a family home on North Berwickrsquos High Street turned down by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning committee.The proposals, recommended for approval by planning officers, were rejected by a single vote.Mr Sutherland, who works in the town, appealed to Scottish Ministers to see the plans given the green light.Rosie Leven, the reporter appointed by the Scottish Ministers, gave the planned three-storey building at  High Street and land to the north the go ahead.Neighbours overlooking the proposed three-bedroom house had objected to the planned property, which measures just over four metres wide and  metres long, on the grounds of privacy.Mrs Leven attached a condition to the approval that a balustrade should be included on the roof terrace.She said: ldquoI consider that the proposed first floor kitchen doors and roof terrace are part of the main living space of the proposed house and are likely to be more regularly used, during a larger proportion of the day, than the bedroom windows.ldquoI consider that it is from those first floor windows spaces that there is the greatest potential for an adverse effect on neighbouring residential amenity.ldquoIn this respect, the appellant has suggested that a condition could be placed on the consent to require a . metre balustrade around the three open sides of the roof terrace.ldquoIn the circumstances, I find that such a balustrade would help to reduce the ability for overlooking, both from the roof terrace itself and from the double doors to the kitchen.ldquoTaking this into account, I accept that there may be some overlooking from and to the proposed bedroom window, but with the addition of a balustrade, I consider that the overall impact on the amenity of the neighbouring properties would not be signicantly adverse.Concerns had also been raised about whether the proposed building was in keeping with the character of the town centre.The Reporter noted that traditional buildings ldquodominate the area but added ldquothere are dferent heights and styles of building.She said there was ldquono consistent building line on Forth Street and the character is one of buildings offset from each other, providing interesting views and angles.The proposals originally went before the local authorityrsquos planning committee in January, with six of the  councillors voting to reject the plans.Councillor Jane Henderson was joined by fellow North Berwick Coastal ward members Jim Goodfellow and Jeremy Findlay in speaking out against the plans.She told the committee that the width of the home would be ldquonot much wider than a shipping container, my goodness gracious.She said: ldquoI am not convinced this is the best place for a Grand Designs experiment, adding: ldquoJust because theoretically it can be done does not make it right.Grand Designs is a popular and long-running home improvements television show presented by Kevin McCloud where unique and daringly designed homes are built.

title: nicola-sturgeon-covid-update-today-learned-announcement
story: Covid cases in Scotland have fallen in recent weeks, which is due immune response fromboth vaccination and an element of people being infected with Covid, according to the first minister.The Scottish government was criticised last week after many people had problems with downloading the NHS Scotland Covid Status app.Changes to the rules surroundinginternational travel also came into force as Scotland chose to participate in a four nations approach.It means that the same rules will apply wherever you travel in the UK.As Scotland continues its journey towardspost pandemic recovery, heres what we learned from Nicola SturgeonsCovid update today...The first minister confirmed that there would be no changes to the "albeit, limited regulations" still in place in Scotland.This is because, according to the first minister, the numbers have continued to fall.However, she also said that despite falling cases, the infection rate still remainsrelatively high which is of concern as we head into the winter months.It is for this reason that the current limited measures, such as mask wearing,will remain in place in Scotland.Explaining this, the first minister said: "the level of infection, though falling, remains relatively high and so we consider that it is prudent at this stage, as we approach winter, to keep in place the remaining mitigations, face coverings for example, for a further period."A total of , daily cases were recordedtoday, a slight increase on yesterdays figures which were below ,.The "signicant and sustained fall" in cases is now being reflected in the number of hospital admissions, according to the first minister.As a result, Nicola Sturgeon continues to remainoptimistic about the general downward trend in numbers, following a period of daily figures topping , throughout August and early September.Describing this as a relief, she said: "Given that cases are continuing to fall, we hope and expect that the number of people in hospital will decline further. We also expect that the number of people dying from Covid will reduce."The mitigation measures currently in place in schools areunder review, particularly whether pupils will continue to have to wear masks in schools after the October break.The body conducting the review is expected to come to a decision on such measures later this afternoon and will then advise the Scottish government.The first minister added that"should they advise that any easing is possible following the October half-term, the Scottish Government will consider this carefully and advise schools of any changes as soon as possible."Nicola Sturgeon acknowledged the problems releated to the app, particularly the issues downloading vaccination status on Thursday and Friday, and apologised.Explaining the source of the problem, the first minister said:"Essentially the high level of demand after the launch of the app ndash combined with an error in one part of the NHS system ndash meant that information wasnrsquot being sent quickly enough from the NHS system to the app."She added: "Indeed, I can report that the initial backlog of people waiting for their information to be matched had been cleared by Saturday lunchtime."Nicola Sturgeon confirmed that although initially the app faced signicant problems, it now works well.She therefore encouraged everyone to download or order their vaccine passport as soon as possible.

title: insurers-cover-distressed-dogs-owners-return-office
story: With many people working from home during the pandemic, many new pets were purchased due to the excess time at home. But now most people are ing to the office, and pets are not used to being left alone.Pet owners may not realise that their insurance policy could include cover for veterinary treatment for their distressed pets, financial information firm Defaqto said.Behaviour cover is designed to pay for therapy to treat emotional distress which could be caused by separation anxiety now that some owners are no longer working from home.Defaqto found more insurers are now offering behaviour cover as part of their pet insurance products, compared with the start of the coronavirus pandemic.Nearly half of dog insurance policies now include full cover for behaviour, compared with % in February .Defaqto cautioned that insurers will exclude cover for claims where the behavioural illness could have been prevented by proper training and socialising.Brian Brown, consumer finance expert at Defaqto, said: ldquoDogs provided much-needed companionship for their owners throughout the pandemic and for those that started le in lockdown, they have never known any dferent.ldquoIt is not surprising then that some dogs are anxious when they are being left alone for the first time and displaying destructive behaviour. The good news is that this is treatable and insurers have stepped up to increase their cover for this.ldquoMany insurers offer free vet helplines where you can get advice over the phone, evenyou donrsquot have to make a claim. If you find you donrsquot have insurance cover, speak to the animal charities to get advice.

story: It comes as Steve Clarkes side continues their quest to qualy for Quatar , after playing in their first major international tournament in -years at the Euros earlier this summer.With the crowd behind them at a packed Hampden stadium, Scotland will look to extend their current lead over Israel in the Group F table.Although its the Scots whocurrently hold second place, Israel is only one point behind meaning everything is to play for in Saturdays match.The good news is that a home gamehas previously proved advantageous inhead to heads, and with the biggest crowd expected at Hampden since , the team certainly wont be short of support.Heres what you need to know about the teamsprevious matches and Scotlands track record against Israel...Since October  , Scotland has played Israel six times, with Saturdays match the seventh in almost exactly three years.Prior to , the teams had not met since the s, when they played twice in  and once in .Of the six matches in the past three years, Scotland has won two of the games.The first triumph came in the UEFA Nations League on November  , when Scotland won - at Hampden in front of a ,-strong crowd.A draw behind closed doors in the same league came next in September , closely followed by a win on penalties one month later during the UEFA European Championships qualiers.Israels wins came at their home grounds on October   and November  .With another head to head incoming, Saturdays match is not the first time the teams have faced each other in this tournament they played in Tel Aviv on March  , drawing -.

Their collective turnover last year amounted to just over poundbn.Read the full exclusive story here.Nearly a third of Scotlandrsquos biggest wind farms have owners with links to offshore tax havens in the Cayman Islands, Luxembourg, Guernsey and Jersey.An investigation by The Ferret has also revealed that  of the largest  wind farms are ultimately ownedoutwithScotland in England, Spain, France, Germany, Norway, China and where.Read the full report here.Nearly  per cent of malt whisky distilleries are ultimately owned bycompaniesoutside Scotland with wealthy people linked to the industry including a French fashion billionaire, an Australian yoghurt tycoon, a Swiss philanthropist and Thailandrsquos richest man.The Ferret can reveal that of the Scots distilleries only a thirdare owned by Scottish firms.Read the full story here.Ten of Scotlands major newspapers are owned by just three men: Rupert Murdoch, Lord Rothermere and Frederick Barclay. They are all billionaires who, personally or through their businesses, have used thelawto avoid paying tax.An analysis by The Ferret reveals that all but one of Scotlands national newspapers, the Sunday Post, are owned in other countries.Read the full storyhereFive privatecompanieswho employ around three quarters of the workforce in Scotlandrsquos arms industry had thousands ofclosed doormeetings with the UK Government between  and .As part of TheFerretrsquosWho Runs Scotlandinvestigation we looked at firmsoperating in Scotlandrsquosdefenceindustry and examined data about them obtained by the Campaign Against Arms Trade .Read the full report here.The chief executives of quangos appointed by Scottish Government ministers were paid over poundm in total last year, leading to ldquoexcessive pay gaps between those at the top and lower paid public sector workers, The Ferret has found.In the course of ourresearchwe looked at the salaries ndash before bonuses or pension tops-up ndash of  leaders of quangos . There are just over  quangos in Scotland, which include Scottish governmentpublic andhealthbodies, executive agencies, non-ministerial offices and commissions.Read the full exclusive story here.Women board members appointed to Scotlandrsquos public bodies get paid half a million pounds less than their male counterparts, despite a drive for gender equality, The Ferret can reveal.Published pay arrangements for board members across  dferent public bodies, where appointments are largely overseen by the Scottish Government, show there are now virtually equal numbers of men and women serving on them.Read the full story here.Influential bankers,retired senior civil servants, well-connected industry insiders, powerful chief executives and former politicians - meet Scotlandrsquos quango class, the people who serve on the boards of Scotlandrsquos public bodies.Some roles are unpaid, and manyworkextra hours intheirdevotion to public service. But analysis by The Ferret of Scottish Government public board positionshas also found a web of influential connections binding many serving in the public sector.Read the full analysis here.So who runs Scotland  Thatrsquos been the central question of The Ferret and The Heraldrsquos week-long investigation.Along the way wersquove examined the corridors of power and looked at who gets the most access to ministers ndash and who doesnrsquot.Find out the top most influential people in Scotland here.Scotlandrsquos biggest private landowner has been attacked as ldquomanipulative and ldquoundemocratic after The Ferret revealed that his company lobbied the Scottish Government to stymie plans for a spaceport in Sutherland.A letter released under freedom of informationlawshows thatWildland Limitedmdash which runs three large estates acrossScotlandfor Danish billionaire,Anders Holch Povlsenmdash warned the former ruraleconomyminister, Fergus Ewing, that its planned investments could be endangered by the spaceport.Read the full story here.Scotlandneeds a radical sht in the way that power and influence are distributed to help address democratic deficits and rebuild trust in the political process, The Ferret has been told.Politicians and campaigners reacting to our week-long investigation ndash Who Runs Scotland ndash claimed it has revealed deep flaws in our transparency legislation and a heavy reliance on big businesses based outwith Scotland, including those with links to tax havens.Read the full final story here.

title: letters-tories-tune-1920s-2020s
story: Mr Smith references ldquoThatcher as the big Scottish Tory problem, but the Thatcher-era Secretary of State for Scotland was George Younger. Younger fought to keep steel making in Scotland. He fought to make Prestwick the main cargo hub in the UK, an eminently sensible idea. That he lost to vested southern interestsisnrsquot the issue.Contrast him with the present and previous Secretaries of State, Alister Jack and David Mundell. Like Scottish Tory MPs in general, they simply do not fight on any issue for what used to be called the ldquoScottish Interest. That is the problem for Mr Ross not ldquoclass.Add to that the advancement of an oligarch like Malcolm Offord, a man who apparently believes in cutting state expenditure by one-third , and it seems the Scottish Tories are more in tune with the s than the s. I do not regard ldquonationalism as a real issue in Scotland, butit were, then Mr Ross should be aware that ldquoScottish nationalism would always be preferred over ldquoBritish nationalism.GR Weir, Ochiltree.UNTRUTHS FROM DOUGLAS ROSSIT constantly amazes me ndash but why should it  ndash that politicians can twist the truth any which way they want. In the row over Labour deputy leader Angela Raynerrsquos comments regarding ldquoTory scum, the leader of the Scottish Conservatives suggests at the Tory conference she was referring to the votersand describes them as ldquonormal Scots looking for a party that can stand up to the SNP. They are people like me, my family and my community.Douglas Ross says: ldquoThese voters arenrsquot as Angela Rayner would say lsquovilersquo. They arenrsquot lsquonasty. They arenrsquot lsquoscumrsquo.Ms Rayner was reported as saying: "We cannot get any worse than a bunch of scum, homophobic, racist, misogynistic, absolute pile of banana republic, vile, nasty, Etonian, posh... piece of scum. Some quote that! But the fact is she wasnrsquot talking about the voters, but Prime Minister Boris Johnson and members of his party.So why is Mr Ross allowed to make  accusations and see them reported without any debate Is he simply following his leader and learning the best way forward is to continue to tell untruths because voters donrsquot know any better  And would he tell himself thatrsquos what ldquonormal Scots would expect Andy Stenton, Glasgow.SWISS SYSTEM WOULD HAVE SUITED USON one hand it is encouraging that Peter Russellrsquos proposal for a new Act of Union would include the right of one nation to "withdraw" unilaterally . It is though telling that the requirements he would impose for that nation to do so are not the traditional requirements of the UK polity. The tradition in the UK, which has been used in every election with the exception of the Scottish Assembly referendum in , has been ldquoone vote is enough.Philosophically I can understand Mr Russellrsquos point, but does he not recognise thatthere is to be such a rupture in UK tradition that there is some onus on him to justy this  Political expedience wrapped up in philosophical principle is not a justication for abandoning tradition.I would say Brexit was a major change, but had it come to it, one vote would have been enough. Brexit, as Mr Russell says, might have been a debacle, and like him I consider it a terrible act, but it is the tradition of how the UK does politics.Perhaps mindful of this, the majority requirements he cites are from other than the UK: Switzerland and the United States. The former is particularly interesting, since what he meansis that for a proposition to pass, there must be a national majority but also a majority of Cantons . Applied to the UK, Brexit would never have happened as two "cantons" ndash Scotland and Northern Ireland ndash voted Remain, so denying the double majority that would have been required, had this been the UK tradition. Politically that would have been most interesting in the UK but would be accepted in Switzerland as part of their political tradition.Alasdair Galloway, Dumbarton.BREXIT HAS NOT FUELLED INDY VOTEI WOULD like to thank Ruth Marrfor her response to my letter of October . However, in doing so I fear all she has done is confirm the two main problems the independence movement suffers from: preaching only to the choir and deflecting away from the failures of the SNP.Ms Marr is absolutely right when she notes it is up to the unionists to make the case for the Union. What she and many of her fellow independence supporters fail to understand, and the point I was making, is that a similar burden rests on them to show why independence is better than the status quo. They failed to do this in  and need to convince people like me who voted against independence that it is worth it.I should point out that by Ms Marrrsquos own logic this should be simple. If it is better then it should be easy to list the places where Holyrood is better. Instead, the list of failings from both governments is staggering. While I am old enough to remember a time when the SNP was not in power at Holyrood, people currently reaching voting age are not. And they are much more likely to know who is in charge of what in Scotland and who to blame.As for her reference to Brexit, it should be noted that while Scots may not like Brexit, that does not mean they want to vote for independence to escape it. Support for independence did not increase after the Brexit vote it has not increased much in the years since. In fact, the only time support got above % for anyof time was when the SNP stopped talking about independence to deal with the pandemic. Food for thought there.John Shanks, Glasgow.FIGHT FOR A BETTER UNIONRUTH Marr states the untruth which she frequently peddles, about "crucial decisions affecting Scotland which are made at Westminster by a government Scotland did not elect". As Ms Marr knows only too well, the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland has only one main government, democratically elected, and it is up to us to vote as we see fit when a General Election takes place then she states that "we are currently suffering the consequences of being dragged out of the European Union by a Tory government". As Ms Marr knows, we were dragged out of Europe because the majority of our population voted to do just that ndash not just against a healthy "no" vote from Scotland, but also many other areas of the UK, including London and its surrounding areas. Lastly she states "independence is normal for almost every other country in the world". Scotland is a normal country, and part of the United Kingdom, and therefore independent.I do not knowMs Marr has read Ian R Hamiltons book, No Stone Unturned, retelling the theft of the Stone of Destiny, but that gentleman ndash a strong nationalist ndash makes a fascinating statement as part of his introduction to his book: "If we do not solve the problem of Scottish government, people less moderate than we are will sweep us aside and make of Scotland another Ireland. Our fight is not for separation, but for a better Union, and as such we conceive it to be the concern of every one in the United Kingdom, whether he be Welsh or Irish, Scottish or English."Walter Paul, Glasgow.MOVE IN WITH THE NEIGHBOURSBRIAN Taylor implies that anything north of Hadrianrsquos Wall is part of Scotland , and lots of other writers equate the Scottish English border with Hadrianrsquos Wall. It would be a good ideawe made this a fact by annexing the north of Northumberland to Scotland. The countryside is beautul, the towns lively, and the people are friendly. This would help to "level up" the size of Scotland compared to England, and probably reduce the demand for Scottish independence.Helen Ross, Bridge of Allan.FRIENDLY DISAGREEMENTI WELCOME Michael Sheridanrsquos responseto Neil Mackayrsquos call that we should ldquodo better in the constitutional debate.Some of my best friends are adherents to the SNP cause. They are of course mistaken. But theyrsquore still my best friends.R Russell Smith, Largs.Read more: Keep tribalised blindness out of the Scottish independence debate

title: letters-wind-turbines-acceptable-price-pay-cleaner-power-supplies
story: As an engineer I personally find them pleasing works of design in appearance and fully acceptable in todays world. I have also visited Scotlands hills and coasts over many years, from Sutherland to the borders and all in between. Pylons and towers have not distracted my appreciation or love of our beautul land.Now aged  I recall my childhood in Bridgeton, Glasgow, walking to Hosier Street Primary in the late s in yellow smog-filled streets with my handkerchief tied round my nose and mouth. On removal the white hanky had two dark brown holes for nostrils. And all done four times per day, sometimes for days on end.The effect on Glasgow citizens health was immense in terms of lung disease. The cause was from coal-burning in every tenement and factory chimney.In time smoke controls were implemented but years of work then followed as the city erected scaffolding and buildings were shot-blasted to rediscover the beautul architecture hidden beneath the soot encrusted walls.Part of the Glasgow skyline was also peppered with huge structures called gasometers, like grotesque alien ships, for storing the city gas supplies. Great rusting hulks which rise and fall depending on the volume of gas inside. Not pretty to look at but necessary for the citizens needs at the time.Coal has gone. Nuclear has risks as in Fukashima and Three Rivers events. Oil is to be transitioned away from. So wind and solar has to be in the mix with possibly new hydrogen power options. We just cant have our pristine countryside and reliable power supplies without some penalties. Sorry, but it cant be done.Bob Wolfenden, Biggar.AVOID KNEE-JERK EVERARD RESPONSEI READ with interest the letter from Denis Bruce .He makes a number of well thought-out and well-intentioned suggestions, several of which are unfortunately unworkable.All the talk of ldquo the arrestee and about at least two officers and no handcuffs is commendable but would change nothing and could in fact make matters worse.Back in the day I made more than one off-duty arrest whilst alone. For example, one was in the middle of the night and it was an inidual who had broken into several cars and stolen a lot of property. Another was in the middle of the afternoon. I had become suspicious and followed an inidual into a very secluded wooded area. He was with a very young and very distressed child and I intervened seconds before before he raped her. He was a big man with inordinate strength. This was horric andMr Bruce had his way then presumably I would have had to just stand by Regarding handcuffs only for violent prisoners, then this takes no account of those who subsequently become violent or who secrete drugs or weapons on their person. They need to be secured before they can dispose of the drugs or use the weapon against the arresting officer.The events surrounding Sarah Everard are beyond evil. I truly cannot think of a more horric set of circumstances. I am confident that every serving and retired police officer , will be embarrassed, ashamed and mortied.I think it is incumbent on the entire police service , to carry out a root and branch reform of its recruitment processes and what should be far more stringent processes applicable to those who become authorised firearms officers . We currently have interviews, written exams, assessment processes for normal recruits and psychometric testing for AFOs but clearly this monster slipped through the net. The police service could take advice from other police agencies throughout the world and they could look at how operatives to our internal secret services within the UK are recruited. The police service clearly do not have a monopoly on all the answers.Something is wrong and needs fixed. It needs to be done calmly, and methodically. It cannot be done as a knee-jerk reaction.Stewart Falconer, Alyth.SCHOOL LIFE WAS JUST PANTSHOW things have changed from my time at a single-sex girls school from  to . I was reminded of what it was like when I saw the photo of the young ladies of St Columbas High School sanitising their handsI am afraid it wasnt the parents problem that interested me but whether the young ladies have to wear school knickers as "Victorian" as the ones in my day. I doubt it, as those pupils would probably not agree to wear the near-bloomers with strong elastic which were de rigueur. We had bottle-green oneswith a small pocket in which to keep ones handkerchief.The unorms we wore were tunics which came to the knee until, joy of joys, in the sixth form we were allowed to progress to skirts which came to near the ankles. It was the time of the "new look" so we felt very fashionable. I still wear skirts at ankle- and never trousers though I have given up on voluminous knickers with pockets.Thelma Edwards, Kelso.BOND WONT SAVE CINEMAWITH reference to the article by Karen Peattie film will be good for our economy", The Herald, October  it will take more than one Bond movie to revive cinema attendance.As a regular cinema attender prior to Covid my attendance has declined signicantly since restrictions eased. Not because of health concerns but because of the lack of quality films being released.The emergence of streaming channels during the pandemic has changed viewing habits, which could spell the longer-term demise of cinema attendance.Bill Eadie, Gfnock.

title: stormers-clash-golden-opportunity-mike-blairs-edinburgh-bounce-back-defeat
story: The South African side are zero from two in the competition so far and missing their Springbok stars. However, head coach Mike Blair believes that all four of the South African sides which have joined the league this year are getting stronger as they become accustomed to playing in European conditions, so has warned his team that they canrsquot afford to start slowly.ldquoTheyrsquore used to the type of game over here now with two games under their belts, Blair reasoned. ldquoStormers had an excellent first  minutes or so against Munster and not many teams go there and are  points up near half-time.ldquoMunster got back into it through their driving game, but Stormers when they hit their straps are a dficult team to stop.Blair added that while Edinburgh wonrsquot underestimate the challenge they face this coming weekend, the team will approach the match with confidence having quickly compartmentalised their loss to Benetton.ldquoWe had a team meeting and were frustrated, he explained. ldquoWe talked about shooting ourselves in the foot. But there was a load of positive stuff too, so it was a positive meeting about the good things that wersquove been doing.ldquoBut we did also reflect on the fact that we canrsquot give the opposition easy ins to the game through our basic errors, whether thatrsquos discipline or skill-based stuff.ldquoAfter  minutes we kicked the ball out on the full, and on  minutes  second wersquove got a line-out on their  to win the game, so you look back and of course yoursquore frustrated with how it turned out. But, as I said to the guys, itrsquos not asthese are dficult things to fix. We can turn these things around pretty quickly.ldquoThey were six wins from seven, playing at home, sowe had won that game that would have gone down as a really good away victory, he added. ldquoWe canrsquot then turn around and say it was a shocking loss.One of the big success stories for Edinburgh so far this season has been the form of Ben Vellacott, the -year-old scrum-half who joined the club from Wasps during the summer and has added an energy to the capital outfitrsquos play which was conspicuously absent last season under Richard Cockerill.Vellacottrsquos recruitment may have happened before Blair took up the capital reins, but the coach has been a long-time admirer.ldquoHersquos done well, hasnrsquot he  said Blair. ldquoHersquos someone we watched nationally for a few seasons. He had a bad knee injury [in September ] and didnrsquot get a huge amount of rugby after that. I was in touch with him a couple of years ago and gave him a bit of feedback on a few dferent things.ldquoHersquos an exceptional player. Give him front foot ball and hersquos going to tear the opposition apart. And the pleasing thing with Ben is hersquos not been a one-trick pony. Hersquos been able to play at tempo. but hersquos shown a really good organisation as well.As the nationrsquos most capped scrum-half and a former member of Gregor Townsendrsquos Scotland coaching team, Blair is ideally placed to assess whether the new man has got what it takes to push his way into the international frame this autumn.ldquoI think Scotland have strong scrum-halves, and George [Horne] and Ali [Price] probably have a fair bit in the bank, but the way that Ben is going,he can continue to show this consistency, hersquoll start pushing those two along with Jamie Dobie and Scott Steele, Blair said.Vellacottrsquos fine form has not been good news for the two other scrum-halves in the Edinburgh squad, with -year-old Henry Pyrgos managing eight minutes off the bench in round one against the Scarlets and -year-old Charlie Shiel being an unused sub against Benetton.This lack of game time is a particular concern with respect to Shiel, who has been on the books since the summer of  and has  appearances to his name, but only  starts. He is a player who has been on the verge of a breakthrough for three years, without ever getting a real run in the team.ldquoIt is dficult, said Blair. ldquoI am trying to give guys opportunities, but we donrsquot have Super we can fall back on because Covid means we need a week between playing Super and then coming back with us.ldquoI am as frustrated as these guys are because I am giving them feedback and telling them what they need to show, and the guys are saying: lsquoI know, but Irsquom not playing!rsquoldquoI know that answer is coming so I need to be able to facilitate ways for the guys to show me what they can do in training.

title: vaccine-passport-means-sturgeon-issues-update
story: After MSPs voted to back proposals to introduce vaccine passports, a law has come into effect under which nightclubs and large events will only be able to allow entry to people who can show they have had two doses of a Covid vaccine.The newly introduced scheme is seen as a way of allowing events to go ahead as Covid- is still in the community, and to avoid re-imposing wider restrictions. It has also been seen as a way of encouraging the uptake of the vaccine in younger people.While the law came into effect from  October, but it will not be formally enforced until October  to give venues time to test out their procedures.:Sturgeon apologises for deeply regrettable problems with vaccine passport appIn Nicola Sturgeonrsquos speech todayshe acknowledged the initial issues affecting the NHS Scotland Covid Status app, but confirmed that it now works well.She therefore encouraged everyone to download the app or order a paper copy of their vaccine passport as soon as possible.Once the law is enforced on October  operators of events will be committing an offencethey do not have some kind of checking system in place, and could face a fine.People over the age of  will need to show that they have received both doses of a Covid- vaccine,asked, to gain entries to certain venues and events.The Scottish Government said that the scheme will apply only in the following higher risk settings.For nightclubs and smaller events, all people entering should be checked - but venues will be given a month to build up to this.For larger events a "reasonable number" of spot-checks should be carried out, in many cases around one in five.The Scottish Government have proposed the following exemptionsThe Scottish Government has stated that there are a very small number of people in Scotland who cannot be vaccinated for medical reasonsof the population.Medical exemptions will allow those who cannot be vaccinated due to a health condition access to settings that would otherwise require vaccination.Clinicians have identied a very small number of people who cannot receive a complete course of vaccination and they will receive a secure paper exemption certicate in the post.The vaccine passport will be similar to the digital Covid certicate being used across Europe and people who have had two vaccines in Scotland can already download or get a paper copy of a certicate with a QR code.The NHS Scotland Covid Status App allows people to register, using their passport or driving licence to very their identity, and then creates a QR code for each vaccination.Those who cannot use the app will be able to request what the government describes as "a secure, un-editable" paper record.Venues have access to a QR code verier app to check customerrsquos QR codes.

title: celtic-connections-festival-returns-2022-live-performances
story: The event will be held in Glasgow from January  to February , with an -day programme featuring traditional folk, roots, Americana, jazz, soul and world music.More than , musicians are due to eager to capture the collective human experience that is at the heart of whatrsquos been missing for people ndash the sharing of experiences, songs, music and stories.ldquoWhat allows Celtic next generation.The event will also include workshops, theatre productions, ceilidhs and exhibitions.Alan Morrison, head of music at Creative Scotland, said: ldquoItrsquos a delight to see Glasgow title: hopes-new-pay-deal-end-months-scotrail-disruption-strike-announced-cop26
story: The Scottish Government said that it is hopeful that a ldquofair pay increase can be agreed for staff.ScotRail engineers have alreadyvoted to take part in a series of strikes during the COP climate conference in Glasgow, which starts at the end of this month.Around , people from all over the world are expected to descend on Glasgow from November  for the climate summit.The Scottish Government said it was hopeful "an appropriate and fair pay increase" could be agreed while talks between unions and ScotRail bosses concluded yesterday with further negotiation expected to continue with the train drivers union Aslefand further discussions on Thursday.Unions say ScotRail bosses sought to link a pay offer with a reduction in ticket office opening hours, a move that has already been rejected.They have urged the First Minister to intervene.The rail operator controlled by Dutch state transport firm Abellio has cancelled numerous services following a pay dispute with train conductors.Rail services across Scotland have been disrupted for months by industrial action, with disagreements over pay and planned cuts in the wake of reduced passenger numbers as a result of the pandemic.Transport minister Graeme Dey said that the unions and management were being "actively encouraged" to seek a resolution.He said: "We need to step back from some of the rhetoric that has been dominating the agenda of late and focus on trying to get a suitable outcome to this - but we are in a challenging position, financially."Mr Dey explained that prior to the pandemic, the government was spending around pound.bn a year on Scotlands railways - a figure which has now risen to more than pound.bn. "That isnt sustainable, so we have got signicant challenges."He said the government was encouraging the company and staff to consider where efficiency savings could be made, in part, to fund a pay increase.Mr Dey added: "I understand that later today the unions and ScotRail are meeting and a fresh offer is likely to be tabled - its one I hope that the unions will view in the spirit that it is going to be made and consider settling these disputes."The Unite union said engineers will take part in a series of strikes in the coming weeks because of ldquoreckless actions of management at Abellio.The -hour strikes will take place between October -, November -, November - and November -.A number of stations will be affected by the strikes including Glasgow Queen Street, Glasgow Central, Edinburgh Waverley and Perth.Meanwhile the former commissioner of the Infrastructure Commission for Scotland has raised concerns about the public transport sectors ability to recover following the pandemic.Professor Iain Docherty was answering an urgent question raised by Labour MSP Paul Sweeney at the Net Zero, Energy and Transport Committee.He argued that the lack of public transport use has been driven by ldquoeconomic imperatives as many are questioning whether they will commuting into the office as much following the pandemic.ldquoI think itrsquos going to be challenging for the public transport sectors to recover patronage, said Mr Docherty.
